DEBATE.TITLE: BUILDERS LABOURERS' FEDERATION (CANCELLATION OF REGISTRATION) BILL 1986BUILDERS LABOURERS' FEDERATION (CANCELLATION OF REGISTRATION-CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 April, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration) Bill and the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration-Consequential Provisions) Bill, which are before the Senate, is to cancel the registration of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation, commonly known as the BLF, under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and to make provision for the consequences of that deregistration. I personally thank the Government and the members of the Australian Labor Party for showing the way.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall that when we were in government I had strongly argued to our Government that that was the path we should take-that we should simply legislate to deregister that union. The members of the Fraser Government said that that would not work, that it was too harsh a procedure, and that the union movement would not accept it. They said that we should take the course of going through deregistration proceedings in the Federal Court. That case was proceeding at the time of the Federal election in 1983. It had been started in 1981. I do not think there is any doubt that at that stage the whole of Australia believed that that case should have been brought to a conclusion, but one of the first acts of this Government in office was to apply to the Federal Court for an adjournment of the proceedings against the BLF so that it could enter into some sort of sweetheart deal with that union.

I remind the Senate of the approach of the Australian Council of Trade Unions to industrial disputation under the presidency of the present Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. The game plan then was to let crippling behaviour run its course and only then would the great white hope emerge from the woodwork where he had closeted himself while the disputation was running its course. He would try to present himself as the great white hope who in some way or other had conciliated the dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did it well, didn't he?

—I agree with Senator Chipp. He did do it well. He used to stay away for weeks. We would not hear anything from him; then, suddenly, he would appear as if he were a knight on a charger, just when everyone knew a dispute was coming to an end, and present himself as the saviour of the nation. The destruction that was wrought in this country under his presidency of the ACTU is being felt by this Government at present, as it was felt by the Fraser Government when we were in office. Clearly, the Prime Minister saw himself in that role and, and in some way or other, he still sees himself in that role. There can be no other explanation for this Government's belated behaviour. I ask the Senate: Did this Government really believe that the leopard would change its spots? Why did he choose to ignore the BLF track record, which has been known for so long? Why did he ignore the judgments of Mr Justice Joske, Mr Justice Smithers and Mr Justice Franki?

SPEECH.PARA: In the 1974 deregistration proceedings, Mr Justice Smithers dealt at length with the reasons for cancelling registration. He said that the then executive officer of the union had tried to establish an unreasonable domination of employers, and indeed of employees, by intimidatory actions, arrogant, vulgar and insulting communications, mass violence to property and menaces, sometimes in mass and sometimes terrifying to persons. That track record continued. Notwithstanding, in 1983 the Government sought the adjournment of the proceedings which we had instituted. Can the Government deny that in 1983 and early in 1984, by attempting to buy out the BLF with the employers, it was doing a deal which was deliberately planned to circumvent its own wage guidelines as set out in the accord? Is it not true that a deal was contrived between the Government and the building trade unions, including the BLF, in the run up to the 1984 election?

When the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission refused to give its seal of approval to this deal which involved a BIRPA-a marvellous acronym, a building industry recovery procedures allowance-and which was clearly outside the Government's guidelines, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, personally approved a non-contributing superannuation deal for the building industry, the cost of which would be about the same as BIRPA. Last year, the Government introduced another Bill to speed the deregistration of the BLF. For over a year the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has struggled with the case, with hundreds of witnesses, thousands of pages of transcript, and at enormous cost, and inevitably it has reached the conclusion which we all knew it would.

Mr Justice Ludeke, in his judgment, said that the BLF had no standards as the word was currently understood but reacted to events according to the view taken at the time by the union's federal management committee. The Bench found that since 1976 the BLF had breached eight industrial agreements as well as undertakings given to the Arbitration Commission. The finding was based on BLF industrial action in 10 major disputes, including the $9 campaign in 1984, the 36-hour week campaign in 1984-85, the Melbourne Cricket Ground light towers dispute and the Sydney Police Centre dispute. Is the Government saying that it was not aware of those disputes at the time, that it did not know the way that the BLF was behaving? Did the Government really have to wait until the Full Bench of the Arbitration Commission, led by Mr Justice Ludeke, told us about these matters? The Bench said that control of the BLF was firmly in the hands of the union's federal management committee. Did the Government not know that? Mr Justice Ludeke continued:

Instead of a rational policy designed to advance the interests of the members, the federal management committee is addicted to slogans such as `Dare to Struggle, Dare to Win', `Most Harm to the Boss, Least Harm to the Members' and `An Injury to One is an Injury to All'...the federal management committee has waged its campaigns, leading the rank and file from one disaster to the next...
The efforts of the leaders have caused hardship to the workers and aroused the hostility of the other building unions.

Here we come to the crux of the matter. Instead of allowing the Arbitration Commission to deal with the BLF as per the Government's legislation, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and this Government have decided on a whole new ball game. Mr Willis said that where a union is:

...engaged in conduct which contravened agreements or undertakings to which it was a party, which seriously hindered or prevented the achievement of objects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, or was inimical to the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by conciliation and arbitration.

They are the guidelines set down by Mr Willis and this Government and in those circumstances the Government will legislate to deregister the union. We have the formula for the future. The principles will be that, where a union contravenes agreements or undertakings which seriously hinder or prevent the achievement of objects of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Government will legislate to deregister that union.

We will be looking forward to a very busy legislative program and, when we get back into office, we will know the rules of the game. We know that, when we get back into office, when we as a Government become satisfied that a union is contravening agreements or undertakings which seriously hinder or prevent the achievement of objects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, we will be able to legislate to deregister the union and, as we are giving this Government support, we will expect support from honourable senators opposite when they are on this side of the chamber. These Bills are the model. The Government has shown us the way and set it all out for us. I can assure the Minister that I shall be working to ensure that those principles are carried out when we get into Government.

We will want to go even further, because there are some defects in this legislation. It does not tell us about what will happen to the assets of the union. It tells us nothing about what the Government is going to do about the Builders Labourers Federation superannuation scheme which does not appear to be dependent upon registration. It has been reported that Mr Gallagher and his cohorts have withdrawn $1.5m from bank accounts and that that money is now being carried around Melbourne in bags. Is this money the property of the union? Is this Government doing anything to protect the property of the union members? I am sure that, if the directors of some company were to involve themselves in this type of action, members of the Australian Labor Party would be up in arms talking about the rights of the shareholders. What about the rights of the ordinary individual members of the union? Is the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) aware of the same rumour, which we have heard repeated so often that there has to be some fire behind it, and is it true that the Builders Labourers Federation union officials plan simply to take over-and I will name the union-the Amalgamated Society of Carpenters and Joiners of Australia and continue their standover tactics and thuggery? Has the Minister heard that rumour? What is he going to do about it?

What action has the Federal Government taken to ensure that the State governments exercise the powers that are available to the States but which are not available to the Federal Government to ensure that the funds and superannuation funds of the rank and file members of the union, the ordinary decent people working in this industry, are protected? Can the Minister give an assurance that he has taken the necessary steps, through his State colleagues, to ensure that the assets in the superannuation fund of these people are in some way or other protected? There is no evidence. Mr Willis has not said anything in his speech about it and there is not of course anything in these Bills which may indicate that that is happening. We support this legislation because the case against the Builders Labourers Federation is simply overwhelming.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—I hear Senator Coleman over there say: `Why?' We know that Senator Coleman is one person in the Australian Labor Party who does not support the legislation. We know that there are a large number of people over there who, if we called the division, would cross the floor or walk out of the chamber, but they certainly would not vote in support of this legislation. We are well aware of that. Nevertheless, we will not be calling any division on this legislation, because we will support it.

SPEECH.PARA: The evidence against the Builders Labourers Federation is simply overwhelming. It must be deregistered. We might say to the Government that, if it likes to take similar action against other maverick unions, we will also be supporting the Government in relation to that. There is absolutely no justification for allowing the Builders Labourers Federation to continue to participate in the conciliation and arbitration process for which it has demonstrated absolute contempt and this warning should be heeded by other unions that engage in similar behaviour. The union has outlawed itself and has no right whatsoever to expect any of the privileges of a union registered under the Act.

Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would know there is another flaw in the legislation and that is that the proposed deregistration is for a term of only three years although Mr Willis has indicated that if the Government is not satisfied in three years it would be prepared to extend the term. We say that that is simply not satisfactory. The BLF's behaviour warrants a term of at least 10 years, a term which would be quite long enough to enable the current leaders of the organisation, who have so misled the people in the union down the wrong path, to retire and get out of the industry altogether, to go on the old age pension or whatever they will retire on and to get right away from the union movement. A period of 10 years would enable this to happen. When we get to the Committee stage of this legislation I will move, and the Opposition parties will support, an amendment to make the deregistration extend for a period of 10 years. Three years is simply not long enough to put this union out of business. From the way it has been behaving a term of 10 years is the minimum. We say that the Government has failed in its responsibilities insofar as the rank and file members of the union are concerned in ensuring that both their assets and superannuation funds are adequately protected.

For far too long this Government has turned a blind eye to the excesses of maverick union officials. Belatedly it is now taking some positive action and we applaud that. It is essential that the very roots of this organisation are destroyed and that it is not able to engage in some bottom of the harbour arrangement that allows it to re-emerge under another union banner. The Government has an obligation to talk to its colleagues within State governments to take action to ensure that this union is put out of business permanently. It also has an obligation to apply the same rules to other maverick unions which hold the normal processes of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in contempt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration) Bill 1986 and the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration-Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986 which have been brought into the chamber by the Government. However, in doing so I wish to express very grave misgivings indeed about the form of the legislation. If I had any mild misgivings before Senator Lewis rose, the fact that he is so infatuated by this legislation and sees it as a model for the future simply reinforces the concerns which I have had.

SPEECH.PARA: Parliament is being asked to legislate directly to abolish the Builders Labourers Federation's existence as an organisation which has rights within the federal conciliation and arbitration system. It is highly likely that the force of what we are doing will have that direct impact. Of course the Executive might decide not to present the Bill for royal assent but that is highly improbable. So one can truly say that it is the Parliament which, when this Bill becomes law, will achieve what is set out in clause 3 of the major Bill before us entitled `Cancellation of registration of Federation' and which reads:
The registration of The Australian Building Construction Employees' and Builders Labourers' Federation under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 is, by force of this section, cancelled.

So what is happening is that the Parliament is cancelling the registration of not only the Builders Labourers Federation but also, given the definition of a non-registered organisation in clause 3 of the Consequential Provisions Bill it extends this penalty to any other non-registered association formed in connection with the building industry, a majority of the members of which are, or have been, members of the Federation. It is quite clear that the intention of the two Bills is plainly not merely to restrict the right of the Federation to participate in the federal industrial relations system but also to restrict the right of the present membership of the Federation to participate in that system except through those organisations to which coverage of those members is awarded by way of regulations made pursuant to the Consequential Provisions Bill. I emphasise that all of this is to be done by legislative fiat, by the action of the two chambers of the Australian Parliament.

In chronological sequence this Bill was presented after the review of the activities of the BLF by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The legislation was introduced after the declaration by that Commission, which in a summary form is to the effect that the Commission was satisfied that the BLF had contravened undertakings given to the Commission, the Industrial Registrar or the Federal Court, had engaged in conduct that prevented or seriously hindered the achievement of an object under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, and had engaged in conduct which was inimical to the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by means of conciliation and arbitration.

Whilst it is true that in chronological sequence it comes after all those hearings by the Commission over many days, listening to many witnesses, it must be strongly emphasised that this Bill and our passage of it are in no way dependent on those declarations by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. There is no linkage to this in the Bill, as there would have been had the Minister acted in reliance on the declaration under the legislation that we passed last year. There is no requirement, as there was for the Minister, for example, that members of this Parliament take into account or even read the findings of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in relation to this matter.

It is very important, I believe, to contrast this legislation with the legislation passed last year. That legislation vested the decision to strip the BLF of these rights within the federal conciliation and arbitration system in the Minister, that is, in a responsible member of the Executive Government-responsible in many senses of the word, not only responsible as the ultimate bearer of political responsibility in this area, but also responsible, I believe, in a much more important sense in this case, as someone required by the legislation to act responsibly. Any conclusion reached by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was preliminary to his exercise of independent judgment. The exercise of his judgment required him, I believe, to take into account and assess the findings of the Arbitration Commission, and supplement it with any representations made by the BLF by which it sought to demonstrate either that the findings were quite ill-founded or that, despite the findings, deregistration was not warranted in the public interest. At least, that is how I read the probable requirements of section 5 (1) of the legislation which we passed last year. Indeed, it was also clearly the understanding of the Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth. I have here a transcript of proceedings in the High Court of Australia in the matter of an application for a writ of mandamus against the members of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission brought by the BLF. Before Mr Justice Mason in chambers Mr Griffith, the Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth, as recorded at page 27 of the transcript, stated:

. . . Your Honour . . . looking ahead, if there were a declaration, the minister does intend, Your Honour, to give notice to the Federation of what he is minded to do and to give them an opportunity to make representations about it.

He went on to say, a few pages later, that that was a matter of common decency, which is a shorthand way of saying it is a matter of natural justice and ordinary administrative law that if one is to exercise a power to strip an individual, or an organisation, of rights which he has one ought to do so after giving that person an opportunity, before one exercises that discretion or judgment, to make out his case for one exercising that judgment or discretion in his favour. Under the legislation we passed last year, in other words, the responsible Minister would have had to weigh up the evidence and act to that extent in a quasi-judicial fashion before forming an opinion, as outlined in the section to which I have referred, that the public interest required that the cancellation of the participation of the BLF in the Federal Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should go ahead. This Bill has none of those features of responsible decision making in the sense I have outlined. It substitutes the Parliament for the Minister as the deregistering body and it does not require in its terms that any such assessment of the Commission's findings be carried out by the members of this or any other chamber.

I have read the 66 pages of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission finding and I am sure that Senator John Siddons has done the same because we are responsibly participating in this debate. But under this Bill there is no need for us to form any view whatsoever or even read the Commission's findings. The Bill simply rests on the formation of a political judgment which could take a host of considerations into account, none of which can be reviewed as to the relevance or legality as would have been the case with the Minister under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. If the Minister were to form an opinion and take into account quite irrelevant political considerations, that could have been challenged in the courts as to the legality of the process of his decision making, not as to the merits of his opinion. I am scrupulously avoiding contradicting the assessment of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission as to whether or not the BLF ought to be deregistered. I am talking about the legal propriety of the way in which one goes about such a process.

It seems to me that in short we are engaged in a process which at least in my view is very likely to be in breach of Article 22 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which talks about freedom of association and which has been translated into Article 11 of our proposed Australian Bill of Rights. In that respect I concur with the view of the Freedom of Association Committee of the International Labour Organisation, which had this to say in its general principles regarding freedom of association:

. . . legislation which accords to a Minister the power to order the cancellation of the registration of a trade union in the Minister's entire discretion and without any right of appeal to the courts is contrary to the principles of freedom of association.

A fortiori, it is even more so if we put that untrammelled discretion without any right of appeal into the hands of the Parliament. It seems to me that we are very likely to be in breach of those principles of freedom of association. It astonishes me that Senator Austin Lewis-who is a past Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and a current member; I have a tremendous respect and high regard for his work on that Committee-has been able to accept with equanimity the sort of parliamentary action we are undertaking today.

In fact that is rather ironic, this being the very week in which we have made such laudatory comments about our late colleague Senator Alan Missen, and particularly as during those comments reference was made to his courageous resistance to attempts by the Menzies Government simply to dissolve the Communist Party of Australia by naming it in a piece of legislation.

The fact is that the Communist Party Dissolution Act was struck down in the High Court of Australia primarily because that Court considered it beyond the constitutional pale that Parliament should simply by making a declaration and naming the Communist Party of Australia dissolve it. There was a question of constitutional power there but I believe that the same principle is at stake: The forfeiture of rights or property should be expressly linked to the carrying out of certain activities which are made offences for the commission of which the forfeiture of rights or property follows. By naming a person, an individual or an organisation, and stripping it of its rights by parliamentary fiat we are harking back to that Communist Party Dissolution Act rejected by the High Court and rejected by the people by referendum. We are going back to the Bills of attainder of Stuart and Tudor times and the Parliament itself I believe is being brought to a very dangerous point.

I raise these matters because of my grave concern which, as I say is now doubly reinforced by Senator Austin Lewis's enthusiasm for and infatuation with the model that he sees being put forward here for future action. However, having said all that it is the case that I will have to vote with the Government on the passage of this Bill. I have now expressed my view as a senator and as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills. Honourable senators will have circulated to them the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest on this Bill. I had earlier expressed the same concerns, although in shorter form, in the Caucus of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party. If anyone understands the principles of solidarity and tight discipline in an organisation, I am sure that the BLF does, and therefore it will not be surprised if, after the full debate within the Party room, in which I have participated, I am bound by the decision reached by the majority in that Party room. The principle of Caucus solidarity is inherent in the operation of the Federal parliamentary Labor Party as an effective political force, and I have agreed to submit to its disciplines, except of course on matters of conscience to do with the creation of human life. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with a great deal of interest to Senator Tate's concerns about the Builders Labourers Federation (Cancellation of Registration) Bill 1986 and allied Bill. I think that he has very bravely put his point of view on the drafting of this Bill. I must say I can sympathise with his concerns. However, essentially, they are concerns that have to be expressed within his Party room. In this chamber, we are confronted with a piece of legislation that we must judge on its merits and accept, reject or amend, but not in a substantial way. In commenting on what Senator Tate said, I would say, nevertheless, that this legislation to deregister the Builders Labourers Federation was preceded by a very detailed investigation of the affairs of the BLF by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. So, the precedent has been set. It was not simply an arbitrary decision of Parliament to take the law into its own hands; it is acting on a recommendation of the Commission that the BLF should be deregistered. To that extent, I believe that many of Senator Tate's concerns will be allayed if future governments adopt the procedures that have been adopted, in this case with the BLF.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I make clear that the Democrats do support the aim of this legislation, that is, that the BLF should be deregistered. In our view it is absolutely essential, and until that is done the building industry will not get back to some kind of sanity in this country. This level of insanity has been abroad in the construction industry since the early 1970s and it has cost the Australian public enormous amounts of money. We are now confronted with a situation where the Federal Labor Government, in conjunction with two State Labor governments, are supporting the move to deregister this union. In other words, Labor politicians have said that enough is enough, that something has to be done. For that we commend the Government and the State Labor governments that are supporting this action. I want to make clear that the Democrats' concern with the tactics of the BLF is in relation to the executive of the union and not to the builders labourers themselves. We believe they have been led by a very unsatisfactory national executive, and our concern is to see that that national executive is disbanded and that it is not in a position to re-form at some future time. For that reason, we will move an amendment to extend from three years to five years the period that should elapse before the Builders Labourers Federation can apply to the Commission for the reregistration of the union.

I want to spend a little time explaining just why we believe that a five-year period is necessary. The national executive of the BLF has access to substantial sums of money. Three years is not a long time in industrial relations. We believe that, if the period were only three years, that would be insufficient time to ensure that the present nucleus of the federal executive of the BLF could not keep some organisation in place in that three-year period and then immediately apply to the Commission to establish a new builders labourers union. On the other hand, the Opposition has moved that the period be 10 years. We believe that this is far too long to have a prohibition on the forming of a new labourers' union, if the Commission saw that that was warranted. Nobody knows how the situation will settle down after the deregistration becomes effective. It could well be that there is a very serious disadvantage to the builders labourers in being forced to join unions that do not directly represent their particular interests. It is a matter of judgment as to how long the prohibition should be, and it will be a matter of observation to see how well the situation works after the present BLF is deregistered. We think that five years would be about the right time. That no doubt would include some penalty on the builders labourers because of the fact they will not be allowed to apply for a union of their own in that period. Nevertheless, we cannot support the Opposition's amendment of 10 years because we believe that is unreasonable.

The sooner we can get on with the passing of this legislation the better, so I do not wish to unduly delay the Senate in voting on this matter, but one or two observations are necessary. It is significant that at present three Labor governments in the country, the Federal and two State Labor governments, are supporting deregistration. The previous President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Cliff Dolan, had the following to say about the BLF on Monday, 19 August 1985 when his organisation deliberately and clearly distanced itself from the BLF and its activities:

The ACTU cannot and will not give unequivocal support to the BLF and its activities. The ACTU is not prepared to act as guarantor to the BLF commitments in view of the questions raised as to their compliance to these agreements.

In other words, the ACTU is officially abandoning the BLF. It is no longer prepared to lend its name to the BLF's actions because the union will not stick to agreements and cannot conduct itself in a reasonable manner or be relied upon to honour its word.

It is not only the ACTU that has had reservations. The BLF has been disaffiliated from the New South Wales Trades and Labour Council and from the Victorian Trades Hall Council over the last few years. The New South Wales disaffiliation was the end result of years of violence committed by the BLF against other workers and their unions, culminating in the extraordinary events at the police headquarters in Sydney. Charges were laid against BLF members. Workers in other unions had material, including steel and concrete, thrown at them from above, union officials had their lives threatened and their cars damaged, and workers were assaulted in hotels. In other words, the affairs of Al Capone had nothing on what was going on in this country for a while. In Victoria there were equally bloody incidents relating to who should operate scissor lifts on building sites. The BLF attacked the tradesmen's unions with such ferocity that the rest of the union movement said `This is enough, we will end our support for the BLF'. Without going through the long list of criminal acts laid at the door of the BLF, I feel it is important that action be taken, so we are supporting this legislation.

The question of union power and its abuse is of great concern to the Australian Democrats. I believe action has to be taken in other directions. For example, I believe the Transport Workers Union of Australia needs to be disciplined by governments in some way or another. Right now the TWU is attempting to set unreasonably high prices for the carting of beer from Castlemaine Tooheys Ltd and Carlton and United Breweries in Queanbeyan to hotels and licensed bottle shops here in Canberra. That amounts to an enormous restrictive trade practice. The union wants to fix the price of a load of $420 when other carriers are prepared to carry the same load for $150 to $200. The action of the TWU amounts to standover tactics and should be investigated. I raise the matter in this debate only to point out that there is wide concern in the community about the abuse of union power. I do not think it is good enough for Labor senators to stand up and say when anyone criticises a union that we are union bashing. There has to be discipline. Some brake has to be put on the widespread abuses by unions such as the TWU. I hope the Government will take the necessary step before too long to do this.

There is no doubt that a union that is led badly by a hard core and disciplined national executive can cause untold damage. Our concern is directed against the executives of the unions and certainly not against the unionists themselves, and we believe government action should be taken in this direction also. I believe that this Bill will lead eventually to a more harmonious and productive building industry, and that the quicker action is taken the better it will be for both building contractors and the workers in the building industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three years ago the present Government withdrew the deregistration proceedings which the previous Government had instituted against the Builders Labourers Federation. I think this nation should not forget that this Government has given the BLF an additional three years of standover tactics and thuggery because of a massive miscalculation and a massive misjudgment. Of course, there are those people who might say that this is so because of some curious link which at times, particularly at election times, seems to exist between sections of the union movement and this Government. Why did this Government give the BLF three more years in which to stand over Australia? I think that is a question that this Government had better answer. When the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) introduced the Building Industry Bill last August with powers to deregister the BLF he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The time has passed for yet another `last chance'.

That time had passed long ago. The people who have been stood over at incredible expense and at the risk of physical violence over the last three years have this Government to thank for that. The Ministers involved, from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) down, are the guilty men who have allowed this group of thugs to stand over Australia for that time. That last chance point certainly was reached when the previous Government decided to undertake deregistration proceedings. I want to know why the present Government terminated these deregistration proceedings. My colleague in the House of Representatives, Mr Shack, asked last year:

Was it terminal industrial relations naivety? Was it the belief that the mighty word of the Messiah would turn the BLF bad boys into good guys? There is probably something in that suggestion. I do not wish to explore further possible explanations for the Government's stupidity in terminating the deregistration proceedings in the first place. I simply wish to point out that the Government was wrong, that the BLF did over the Government, and that the BLF made the Prime Minister and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations look foolish in relation to the building industry peace agreement.
That was last August in the House of Representatives. Let us hear a coherent and effective response from the Government at last in this place.

There is no doubt that the BLF, which has demonstrated at the extremes the appalling way in which power can be abused in the industrial relations arena, must be deregistered. It is curious to look at the quaint sort of love affair this Government has had with the BLF, even to the extent, of course, of providing it with $52,000 of the taxpayers' money over the last two years to help it to paint things on walls. We already know that the BLF has received funding from the Australia Council for a muralist in residence. We have noted from the `Free Norm' and `Hands off the BLF' graffiti that is spread all over the capital cities and on the private property of the people building those buildings that that has at least improved its style. It is now often in three colours and it looks almost attractive.

The fact is that this Government has, for some incredible reason, not only harboured this group to its bosom and given it additional chances to be good but also rewarded it by providing it with grants to enable it to spread its message on the walls of our cities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that is how democratic societies would act.
—I thank the Minister for his interjection because the reason-
—Congratulations!

—I thank the honourable senator for his interjection, prompted by the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), and point out to him that, had the proper course been taken, the BLF would have been deregistered three years ago and, as a result, would not have been in a position to get $52,000 from this Government to help it daub walls around Australia. That is the inescapable truth that may eventually filter through to Senator Elstob.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue, of course, came up again last August when the Government introduced the Building Industry Bill. The purpose of it, to quote Mr Willis, was as follows:

Its objective is to provide machinery for the cancellation of the registration of the Builders Labourers Federation under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act or to provide for the effective equivalent of such deregistration in parts of Australia . . . we have come to a point where the actions of the BLF are, in our opinion-and, we would believe, in the opinion of the community as a whole-totally unacceptable.
He went on:

It is now patently clear that the BLF leadership is utterly untrustworthy and that it regards undertakings and agreements as mere strategems to achieve a momentary advantage which can then be disregarded at will.

I just interpose there that it is extraordinary that it took Mr Willis until August 1985 to wake up to that. Surely he knew about that back in 1981 when we in fact started to institute proceedings to deregister--

TALK.START.PARA: —Started to institute!
—Indeed we did. Those proceedings were terminated by Senator Robertson's Government.
—It did nothing of the sort.

—They certainly were. The reality is that this Government, having terminated those steps to deregister the union, took until August 1985 to wake up. I will continue with what Mr Willis said in August 1985:

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, its unprincipled, indeed outrageous, mode of operation has created havoc in the building industry, thereby causing extraordinary delays in building programs and crippling increases in costs. Its use of tactics such as breaking concrete pours, reckless application of work bans, resort to walk-offs or `homers', and claims for payments for time on strike, has made industrial relations in the industry a nightmare. Its resort to industrial blackmail, thuggery, violence and intimidation has added a further ugly dimension to its activities.

Those activities were going on in 1983 when this Government came to power; those activities were allowed to go on because of the withdrawal of deregistration proceedings that the previous Government had instituted and that withdrawal was done by this Government. So here we have thuggery, violence, blackmail and intimidation continuing for three years thanks to this Labor Government which has this special relationship with the union movement.

Having said that, I note that this legislation which was introduced last year, which was going to solve all these problems and fix everything, has not been used. Instead of that, the Government has found that it appears to have been a piece of defective legislation and has replaced it urgently by this new piece of legislation. There is no doubt there were some problems and we pointed them out at the time. In fact, Senator Siddons also pointed them out. I was disappointed that Senator Siddons did not refer to the strong point he made last year on this matter. There were defects in that legislation which were pointed out to the Government at the time, but the Government chose to do nothing about them. This raises quite serious questions about its credibility in relation to that legislation. There was no doubt that questions about the problems raised then, which clearly have inhibited the Government from acting under that legislation now, are as proper now as they were then. It has taken the Government until now to recognise that the legislation introduced last year would have been no more effective than the piece of window dressing that many of us considered it to be. It was a gesture; it was full of the same sort of rhetoric that one tends to expect from this Government in this matter. Ultimately it proved apparently to be so defective that the Government had to introduce something else to take its place.

Senator Siddons pointed out last August that he had some problems with that legislation. He said it would be a very dangerous precedent for the Government to deregister a union without bringing in an impartial body. He said that to do otherwise would amount to the Government's acting as the prosecution, judge and jury. That is what he said last time and there would have been some merit in his saying that this time. I certainly will be saying that kind of thing now. One of the defects that we saw at that time with that legislation was that it gave the Minister enormous powers. I quote from Senator Messner who said of that legislation:

It provides the Minister with enormous and various powers to take action to deal with the Builders Labourers Federation. We do not deny that those powers should be vested in the Minister. But I think we should realise that they are very powerful indeed. They provide almost draconian and certainly dictatorial powers to the Minister to choose whatever line he seeks to take to deal with the BLF.

The Senate might remember that at that time questions were raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee that some of those powers and actions by the Minister could well put that Bill in a position where it could be challenged in the High Court on legal grounds. I refer to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's tenth report, 1985, which said:

. . . because the Minister's powers are exercisable on the basis of the Minister's subjective opinion or, in the case of the decision to permit re-registration, no statutory criteria at all, the scope for review as to legality is limited. The powers permitted to be exercised by the Minister to deregister the Federation, to suspend its rights, privileges and capacities, to require the Registrar to alter its rules and to award coverage of its members to another registered organization are powers ordinarily exercised only by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or the Federal Court. . .

The Committee further considers that the vesting of these powers in the Minister calls in question Australia's compliance with its obligations under Article 22 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (dealing with freedom of association) and under the International Labour Organisation Convention concerning Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise.

There are other elements in that legislation last year which certainly raise questions about the capacity of the union to take the matter further and to consider it to be an assault on human rights. In that context, perhaps I might say that the human rights legislation which is at present before this Senate will override any existing legislation which brings it in conflict with the human rights legislation. If this human rights legislation states-as I understand it to state-that there are freedoms of association inscribed in the legislation, we shall clearly face a situation in which the passing of the human rights legislation in its present form appears to override the requirements of this Bill. It will be interesting to hear what Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister representing the Attorney-General, will have to say on that matter, because if the human rights legislation overrides this Bill, we shall have a great deal of interesting litigation proceeding, at least to test whether this is so.

It may well be held that the right to association for a specific purpose-that is, the right to associate in order to get some sort of industrial position before industrial arbitration structures-is meaningful only when it is the right to associate for a purpose, and when that purpose is denied by administrative fiat, by executive fiat or by parliamentary fiat, as Senator Tate has pointed out, then there is a clear problem in relation to the Bill of Rights itself, apart from a clear problem in relation to the existing bulk of law.

I am not suggesting that the Builders Labourers should take action. I am simply warning that under the previous Act, which was defective, there was clear scope for legal challenge, apart from the fact that there was the clear opportunity to appeal to further bodies to circumvent for quite a considerable time any attempt to deregister the body. So, okay, the previous legislation was defective, would not work, and it would allow the Builders Labourers Federation to keep going on and on forever, fighting it through the courts and the judicial system.

To what extent does this present legislation improve that situation? Let us face it: There is a cost and benefit in all matters. The cost in relation to the new Bill is that, as Senator Tate quite rightly pointed out, it makes the Parliament do things that should properly in our society be done by the courts. In other words, it adds a new dimension-in my view, a new opportunity for challenge-to the Bill. Quite apart from the questions of civil liberties that are involved, there are some problems with this Bill. I make these points. The Security of Bills Committee has pointed out, in its report of 9 April, that under this Bill:
. . . the Federation will be deprived of the right to participate in Australia's highly structured Federal industrial relations system.
The Committee states that the intention of this Bill and its associated Bill is:

. . . plainly not merely to restrict the right of the Federation to participate in the Federal industrial relations system but also to restrict the right of the present membership of the Federation to participate in that system except through those organisations to which coverage of those members is awarded by way of regulations.
The Committee has said that whilst it recognises that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission already has broad powers to deregister organisations, it suggests that:

. . . while it may be thought appropriate for a person or organisation to be deprived of rights by a court in accordance with due process of law, it may not be considered appropriate for the Parliament to deprive a person or organisation of rights in this fashion.
This is the basic civil liberty problem. The committee pointed out:
A court may for example declare a person guilty of murder and impose on that person a sentence of imprisonment . . .

But it would be inappropriate for the Parliament to pass a law making such a declaration and imposing such a sentence itself. In other words, it creates the law within which the courts make such a determination but the Parliament itself does not do so. I think that is a more worrying analogy because it harkens back, as Senator Tate mentioned, to the Communist Party Dissolution Bill. Likewise, it would not be considered appropriate for the Parliament to pass a law depriving a political party of the right to participate in Federal elections and depriving members of that party of the right to form another association for the purpose of participating in Federal elections. This has a real relevance and it concerns me greatly. I must say that I am glad to see that this kind of thing concerned Senator Siddons last August, even though it was not developed to the extent that it is in this matter. I would be interested to hear the Australian Democrats position on this basic question of civil liberties.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are concerned about it, Senator, as I said in my speech; quite concerned about it.

—I think it is a matter for concern and, of course, it emerges that these concerns arise only because the Government has had desperately to find some mechanism to correct its incompetence and the disastrous consequences of its incompetence, going back over three years, when it kept on giving the BLF another go, when another go was clearly inappropriate and when another go has cost Australians multi-millions of dollars and added to the costs in Australia. Because of the massive increase in the price of buildings, space and so on these costs have been carried forward into our inflation rate. This is apart from depriving many people in that building industry of employment because of the way money has been wasted that could otherwise have gone into productive employment and activity. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee, of which Senator Tate is Chairman and Senator Cooney and I are members, suggested:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . . it may not be considered appropriate for the Parliament to pass a law depriving a particular organisation of the right to participate in the Federal industrial relations system and depriving the members of that organisation of the right to participate in that system except through other registered organisations. In depriving the organisation and its members of this right the Bill goes to the heart of the rationale for the existence of industrial organisations. In the view of the Committee, therefore, the Bill may be said to trespass both on the right of freedom of association and on the right to organise. While the Federation will retain the right to exist as a non-registered organisation and to organise outside the confines of the Federal industrial system, it will be deprived of its rationale for existence, namely the right to participate in the Federal industrial relations system.

It seems to me that we are providing in this legislation, as we provided in the last legislation, clear opportunities for the BLF to take this matter to the High Court of Australia, for example, in terms of constitutional propriety and the conflict between international conventions. Certainly, if we pass the Bill of Rights within a reasonable period it will enable the BLF to proceed on the basis that this legislation is in clear conflict with the Bill of Rights, unless the Government recognises that the Bill of Rights is a nonsense legislation and should be withdrawn, or else the courts hold that the Bill of Rights is the sort of nonsense legislation that we believe it to be and tend to ignore it.

Nonetheless, we have a situation in which, because of incompetence and indolence-I hope for no other more serious motive-the Government has allowed the BLF to proceed to a state at which even this Government has had to get off its tail and do something dramatic and sudden to bring to an end this thuggery. I, and I think almost every member of this House at least on this side-I am not sure how many honourable senators on the other side-are certainly of the view that the BLF should be deregistered. It is a shame that the rules of the Australian Labor Party on the other side of the House do not allow its members to express their views on such a matter as this. Of course, within our Party, we have the right to express a conscience view. If the democratic processes that exist within our Party existed within the Australian Labor Party it interests me to speculate on how many honourable senators opposite would in fact vote against this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Try us out.

—It would be interesting to see the consequences if any honourable senator opposite had the stomach to call for a division. There is no way that I will call for a division because I am in favour of deregistering the BLF. I think that the way the government is going about it is incompetent, stupid and the result of a serious mistake; that would be the most polite thing to say about it. As I have said, at this stage I cannot impute any more serious motives to the Government because I do not have any evidence to do so. But it is intriguing to me that, in the face of so much evidence of BLF misbehaviour and thuggery, this Government has taken so long to take action. It is polite of me to regard this as incompetence on the part of the Government rather than anything more sinister.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, I wish only that members of the Government had the capacity within their Party rules to express their views on this matter. It is interesting that, if two or three members of our Party express some disagreement with the Party's policy on a particular matter, it becomes page 1 lead material in the media. Yet something like 30 members, as I understand it, of the Labor Caucus are violently opposed to this legislation. The sort of cover that that kind of break has been given in the media has been utterly minimal. Obviously, at best it is simply curious and at worst disgraceful that, firstly, these kinds of double standards should exist in the media but, secondly, that this Government should, by threat of sacking, force its members who do not agree with this legislation to vote for something in which they do not believe. This underlines a basic difference between the two major political parties in this chamber. I note that the Australian Democrats not only often split but appear to take different positions in almost a majority of cases.

This Bill is a very serious one. It is one that the Government is clearly embarrassed about for a whole range of reasons. It is one that demonstrates both the Government's incompetence and a clear split within the Party on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—Senator Elstob says that that is rubbish. Will he deny reports that 30 of his colleagues--
—Just good debate within the Party; that is all-just fair and honest debate.
—The honour- able senator is saying that as a result of that fair and honest debate everyone then became of a like mind.
—Majority decisions rule, and that is how it should be.

—Exactly! In our Party everyone has an individual right. In our Party we have procedures under which the human rights of every individual are paramount. In the Labor Party the rights of the group dominate over the rights of the individual to the extent that no one in that party, if he wants to remain a member of the Party, will have the capacity to vote against this Bill, no matter how fervently he opposes it. That is significant and is one of the most dramatic examples of how the Labor Party, when forced into corners, requires that people support the Party even on matters of major conscience, which this matter is for many people.
—No, it isn't.

—I suggest that Senator Elstob ask some of his colleagues, to whom I have been talking and who have spoken freely and properly to me on this matter, and see whether they regard it as something of major significance.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is a bad bit of law. It comes from an incompetent Government. However, there is probably no alternative at the moment to proceeding along these lines if we want-as I certainly want-to see the group of thugs who run the BLF lose their jobs and this union deregistered. Because of the Government's disgraceful withdrawal of proceedings three years ago and its incompetent delay until last August in bringing forward legislation which now does not work, we have no option but to accept this legislation. All I can hope is that in the inevitable challenge in the courts the Government is supported by the courts and deregistration proceeds. It is in Australia's best interests that it do so.
