SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly not going to use all the time allocated to me in this debate on the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration) Bill 1986 and the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration-Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986, but I will use a short period of it to illustrate a number of points and perhaps answer some of the questions Senator Michael Baume has been posing about the procedures within the Australian Labor Party of which I am a member. I make the point in opening that I take no joy whatsoever in standing here today as a senator for Western Australia and supporting the deregistering of a trade union. I have no joy, as a trade unionist for many years, in taking this course of action. But I am, as was said by Senator Baume who was supported by Senator Elstob, locked into a Caucus decision to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly perturbed at supporting this Caucus decision because it was made on the same day as the Australian Labor Party, a party founded on the trade union movement, took a decision to give a $120m subsidy to the banking sector-four banks of the wealthiest banking sector in the world. We also took that Caucus decision to the strains of some `crying in your beer' music, or country music, from the farmers who were outside the Parliament protesting about what they perceive as their ills and how they are upset in society at the moment. In saying that I have some sympathy for the farmers. We took the decision. People have been disadvantaged by the farmers in a whole number of areas. They blockaded the airport, the Treasury building, Parliament House and the car pool, using tactics they allegedly learned from the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Builders Labourers Federation and other unions. They did all this on fuel subsidised by a Federal Labor Government which at the same time has taken the decision to deregister a union.

I am torn because of my opposition within the Caucus committee which made the decision on the deregistration and my opposition within Caucus itself. I opposed the decision in both places. But I will vote in support of the legislation because I will follow the procedures I accepted when I joined the Australian Labor Party. I am also torn in what could be perceived to be my alleged support of the Builders Labourers Federation because of my membership of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union and, in turn, its membership of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Neither my union at a national level nor the ACTU is supporting the Builders Labourers Federation in its current tussle over registration. So I have a number of conflicts, the final resolution of which is that I will support the procedures followed in my party, although I have expressed some disquiet about those procedures as they operate and about what we are doing.

I want to say a few words about the Builders Labourers Federation. Builders labourers work in an industry which is rough, tough, brutal and dangerous. Those involved in it have an uncertain future. The builders labourers, the ordinary workers on the job who carry the hod for the brickie and do many other jobs, used to be at the bottom of the whole pile. They were really down at the bottom of the pile.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were slaves in that industry.

—They were slaves, and they were used and abused in that industry, not only by the employers, the managers and the foremen but also-I am loath to say-by some of the tradesmen. The Builders Labourers Federation has done a tremendous job in giving some esteem to those very fine people, many of whom would be migrants. Many of them were poorly educated. Big numbers of them did not have a command of the English language and, therefore, were vulnerable to being kicked around. Through the actions of the union, the industry in total-tradesmen as well as labourers have benefited-is now a much safer and more secure industry in which to work. Although there were some problems in the collection of statistics some years ago, they prove that the union, through its actions, has ensured that there has been some degree of redistribution of wealth and that the labourers, who were right down on the bottom rungs of the industry, often working for a contractor or on a contract that had been sub-let, eight, 10, 12 or 15 times, with each sub-contractor taking a piece of the action, a piece of the cake, as the contract proceeded, now have a reasonable wage in most cases. They have some degree of security of employment. The union has to be commended for that.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not going to seek to answer all the allegations regarding thuggery, criminals and others of ill-repute who might operate within the Builders Labourers Federation. I have no doubt that the Builders Labourers Federation, like any other group in our community, has criminal elements involved in its midst. There are thugs on both sides of industry. It takes two to tango. But what has often been overlooked, not only by parliamentarians or politicians at a State and Federal level but also by other trade unionists, by the media and by commentators, is the fact that the Builders Labourers Federation has many fine human beings involved in it-people with compassion, people who care and people who have dedicated their lives to the welfare of their fellow workers. I know a large number of people who work within the Builders Labourers Federation-people who work on the job as labourers, people who are shop stewards and officials of the union. I do not say that I agree with everything they do or have done from time to time, but I understand that sometimes they have seen the need to take the actions they have thought necessary to redress a wrong. In the vast majority of cases they have done so not for self-benefit or self-indulgence but on behalf of their fellow workers in the industry. That point has been overlooked.

When labels are being cast around very freely in the debate surrounding this legislation and the actions of the Builders Labourers Federation, too often the vast number of people who have dedicated their lives to the union have been given the same label and their contribution has been overlooked. People going to large cities such as Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and even Perth see many fine old buildings that have been protected and preserved for future generations through the actions of the Builders Labourers Federation. Collectively, we on both sides of the chamber and society owe a debt of gratitude that cannot be repaid.

One final point on which Senator Cooney will probably enlarge is that of the amendments to the three-year provision before application for reregistration can be made-by the Australian Democrats amendment to five years and by the coalition amendment to ten years. This small point shows a lack of understanding and appreciation of what is involved in industrial relations and the Conciliation and Arbitration Act if they need to put forward such amendments. Perhaps people on the other side do not understand what the Government is doing in putting a three-year clause in the Bill, in the sense that they are not aware-if they were they would not have put forward the amendments-that the three-year clause means that there cannot be even an application for reregistration in that time.

On the last occasion on which the builders labourers were deregistered in the 1970s and reapplied for registration, they had the support of the Government, other unions and employers. In the present frame of mind it is very unlikely that if an application for reregistration were made by the builders labourers they would get the support of government, unions or employers. In the 1970s, even with all their support, it took the builders labourers 18 months to have their reregistration processed. If things turn out the same way-I am accepting that the Bill will go through because I, like my colleagues on this side of the House, will support it-it will be at least three years before an application is made. If opposition to the BLF continues it will take a lot more than 18 months for such a reregistration to take place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration) Bill and the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration-Consequential Provisions) Bill basically seek to bring about the cancellation of the registration of the Builders Labourers Federation and to deal consequentially with that cancellation. The matter before the Parliament arises from an application by the Federal Government on 6 September last year to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to declare that the long history of unlawful actions of that trade union put it beyond the terms of behaviour which would justify continued registration. On 4 April the Full Bench concluded that that was so. I simply read an extract which says:

SPEECH.PARA: It has been established beyond question that the Builders Labourers Federation has rejected the standards of behaviour accepted by most trade unions in Australia. The Federation has no standards as that word is commonly understood, but reacts to events according to the view taken at the time by the Federal Management Committee. Instead of a rational policy designed to advance the interests of the members, the Federal Management Committee is addicted to slogans.

I point out that the legislation before the Senate is very radical. I find no joy in its necessity. Rather than its being a pattern for the future, I hope that we will find ways of remediation and prevention which do not regard it as being an essential battering ram. We ought to regard it as being necessary at the moment and the only available weapon to use to deal with an extremity. We ought to look to the trade union movement to prevent the emergence in future of such extremities.

I find considerable sympathy with many of the comments made today by Senator Tate. I hope that, whilst we all come to the conclusion that we must, of necessity, support this legislation, we will all have a very great regard for the reasons that this has happened, the failure of the Australian community to prevent this kind of happening in the past and the need in the future for prophylaxis and remediation. That is basically why I speak in this debate today.

If anyone believes after this legislation is passed that this matter is over, that person fails to understand the enormous consequences of what has been triggered. In my time in the Fraser Government we were inclined to take this path. I do not seek in any way to establish an argument or tribal war between the parties on the opposite sides of the chamber. At that time it was clear that the Australian Labor Party would not support us and the trade union movement would not support us, and many employers expressed an unwillingness to come forward. We have been through this agony.

I come to the essential point. We are engaged in an extreme action. In some ways I agree with what Senator McKiernan said. I would be the first to pay tribute to the magnificent struggle of the trade union movement over the decades. I am an avid student of the history of the emergence of trade unionism, of the English guild system which emerged to protect the skills and working conditions of its members and, from that, the development of crafts. I am an avid supporter of the principle of true and authentic industrial trade unionism. I am a total opponent of political trade unionism and militant civil war as a means of achieving goals. When looking at this situation let us in this chamber not have the elements of a tribal war. A fundamental fallacy has created the situation and the extremism that exists today. All of us are to blame-the whole Australian community, Liberal, Labor, boss and worker.

We are now, almost unique in the world, peddling an industrial revolution belief that one can succeed against the other in an industrial war. We are being licked hollow, if I may use an Australianism, by countries costing us out of world markets not because their employees receive lower pay-they don't in Japan-and not by lower standards of work, but because they understand that employer and employee interests are identical. If ever a lesson is to come out of this brutality, because we are engaged in dealing with a brutality, it is to get back to the fundamentals of what has caused it. We are facing an inevitable decline. It has been caused attitudinally because we have failed to understand that other countries are working to increase productivity-boss and worker working together-because, unlike the pernicious doctrines peddled in Australia, they know that their interests are identical.

Again, I am an avid student of the arbitration system. Indeed, it was governments of my political faith that established the arbitration system. It is well worth understanding in this silly civil war on trade unionism that governments of my faith put into legislation the power of industrial trade unionism to flex its muscles to get better benefits for workers. Anyone who follows history from 1901 onwards, through the time of Mr Justice Higgins and the `Harvester' case, will see that the Liberal view has been that there ought to be an orderly way to establish living conditions, there ought to be a civilised way of resolving conflicts. Two things should emerge. Fundamentally there is a need to establish a minimum wage below which no one can be exploited and within that a need to establish margins for skill so that skill can be rewarded.

Senator McKiernan talked about the need for labourers to share. One of the dangers in that, and I commend the principle, is that the mob-and I do not use that word in a derogatory sense, but in the numbers game, because there are far more unskilled than skilled-in the industrial unions swamp the skilled. The margins for skill have diminished. We have fought in a brutalised way. What I basically want to say today is that this matter will not be solved in future by saying: `Let us do it again'. If honourable senators think this is the only case, let me read the absolutely ugly words from the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Senator McKiernan said, and I accept it, that there are thugs, villains and criminals in every union as there are probably in every industry. That is just something we must accept. The Royal Commissioner stated:

The Union has attracted to its ranks in large numbers men who have been convicted of, and who continue to commit, serious crimes. They treat the law with contempt, and are scornful of its punishments. They treat law enforcement agencies as their enemies. They are motivated by greed and are not controlled by any consideration for their victims. The only limitation they impose on themselves is that generated by the fear of physical harm should they disobey their group's instructions and directions.

Violence is the means by which they control the members of their group. They do not hesitate to kill. They care not who takes the public offices of their union so long as the encumbent obeys their dictates, as all office holders do. They are careless of their reputation, glorying in its infamy, and by that reputation attracting employment by wealthy people outside their ranks who stoop to use their criminal prowess to achieve their own questionable ends.

No Australian could take any pride in that. If, of necessity, a union must cater for those who, having served their time in prison, must get a job, I understand that and sympathise. Those people, having paid their penalty, deserve to be good Australians and be treated as such. But that report in itself condemns not only that union but also the whole concept of Australia; it condemns not just the Australian Council of Trade Unions but every Australian looking at the trade union movement.

I come to the fundamentals. Why has this happened? It has happened because a union has been able to persuade its members that their interests can be increased by using industrial thuggery against their employers. I am not going to paint the employers as being innocent in this situation. No industrial trade union can exist in future in Australia, and Australian living standards will be destroyed, if beyond this day we allow it to be peddled around Australia that any one group of Australians can succeed by belting the others, by scoring off the others. If there is an ugly concept in Australia today it is the stupid belief that has gone on since the Industrial Revolution that somehow or other we can up our living standards and increase our amenities by taking it out of the hides of others, that somehow or other we can stand up an airline on a basic pretext which is never the one that is important because all the negotiations are done behind the scenes and that that does not matter. Every time we seek to score we diminish not only our quality as persons-I include myself-but also the capacity of Australia and Australians to lift themselves up economically and as human beings.

What has happened? The Labor Party more than anybody has peddled this belief. I do not want to be divisive in what I say. I hope that nothing I have said so far is divisive. The Labor Party has sought to make its gains by taking unto itself a pretended monopoly of the trade union movement and saying: `We are here to protect you against the bosses. The trade union movement must stick to us because the bosses are your enemy'. It has painted the other side of politics as somehow or other supporting the bosses by saying that the trade union movement is its enemy. I cannot think of any more crass nonsense than this kind of warfare.

I pay tribute to Senator Tate who is in the chamber. One does not solve these problems in the long run by radical acts of Parliament. One solves them by changing attitudes of mind. The real trouble in the industrial jungle in Australia is attitudinal. The real trouble is the absolutely outrageously wrong belief that the way to get gains is to develop a commando raid on the boss. Lest anybody thinks that I am siding with the boss I say that the most dangerously foolish decision that was ever made in Australia was made by the employer groups when they decided that they would get together and pay the same standard margin to the most skillful of their people as to the least skillful. The day they did that-employer solidarity-was the day they took all incentive out of industry and all incentive out of the individual to strive to enable himself to get on with the business of productivity. We have to understand that what is necessary in Australia is to encourage people to develop their talents, to pursue excellence.

We have two great messages for the generations ahead of us. One is to work on the whole question of peace and disarmament because unless there is peace and justice in this world there will be no future generations. Running parallel with that is that we have to provide an economic atmosphere in Australia in which our young can get jobs of their choice, jobs that require skill, so that Australian living standards can grow. More importantly, we have to develop wealth so that we can distribute it amongst the underprivileged amongst us.

The economic situation in Australia is this: Our costs of production are too high for us sell our goods overseas and for us to maintain manufacturing and service industries to employ our people. I read today that unemployment amongst the young is rising again; that there are fewer jobs in manufacturing industry and that the brutality of this message is still entrenched in our economy. Unless we can say to employee, employers and governments: `Stop this civil war. Stop this strife. Get together and understand the fundamental problem which is that if you work together to increase productivity you do not put your real wages or your living conditions under any threat at all. Indeed you enhance them'. If we can increase productivity, and everybody can, 5 or 10 per cent in whatever we do, we will be able to build a manufacturing industry again, to export, employ our young and therefore to have a civilised community. That is fundamental to this Bill because I know of nothing that has destroyed job opportunities and productivity more than the industrial warfare that has gone on on both sides. For a very short time of my own career I did a little industrial advocacy. I saw the enormous nonsense that went on, how the dialogue between boss and worker was taken from the factory or office floor and put into institutionalised, polarised conflict. They were problems that ought have been solved a different way. We have polarised conflict. One has to look only at the enormous hours and days that industrial advocates spend in courts, reaping huge amounts of money and widening the gap of disputes when the only place the dispute can be solved in the end is on the factory floor.

I make very clear my views about the loosening up of the labour market. I understand fundamentally that we must always maintain a minimum wage and that that minimum wage must be as high as the country can stand. I insist that there must be proper margins for skill and that in no way must numbers of unskilled be able simply to wipe out the ability of the skilled to gain. The unskilled cannot gain by picking up an extra dollar or two against the skilled. Let me make that clear. The unskilled, like everybody else, have sons and daughters who need jobs. Unless we can enhance skill, unless we can enhance productivity in this country, everybody will suffer. The very fight of the unskilled in the big industrial unions to swamp the others has cut their own throats.

Australia is engaged in a massive civil war of destruction. No other economic thing matters in Australia compared with this one fundamental point: We have a war in office and factory, and we have institutionalised it in arbitration far beyond what was ever envisaged before. Because we have done that both sides of politics, however inadvertently or otherwise, have peddled the absolutely ugly and false doctrine that the one can score off the other.

The Builders Labourers Federation is to have its registration cancelled today because it has pursued industrial thuggery, it has pursued a civil war against the people of Australia and it has pursued duress, blackmail, bribery and every kind of corruption. Its members have gone along with that in the completely false belief that it would benefit them. Yes, workers can take a quick quid for the moment but they cannot score in the long run. If they win today they lose tomorrow because there will be another civil war involving another trade union, firmly entrenched in its view and believing it can score.

I have risen today basically to say that of course I will support this measure. I will look with enormous interest at how the Federation shall progress as a deregistered, unincorporated, voluntary body passing largely out of the Federal jurisdiction into State jurisdictions which I suspect will remain mute and inert. I look toward a trade union with immense funds and immense capacities, and I look also to a trade union movement which on the one hand authentically has the right to attract numbers but on the other hand has in the past indulged in raiding parties. After all, one of the very bedevilments of the trade union movement has been an inability to solve demarcation disputes. I would think that the price Australia has paid for demarcation disputes within the trade union movement has been extraordinarily high. I have watched all this; I have watched the raiding parties over the years.

It will not be an easy journey over the weeks and months ahead. We will see again evidence of illegalities, of thuggery and of everything else. This is not the only union that has got a mote in its eye. Let me pause to say this: I forget the number of trade unions in Australia, but it is in excess of 300. Those of us who indulge in union bashing do a serious disservice to the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you been doing?

—I challenge Senator Georges now to show me in Hansard or anywhere else any word that I have ever said in this place or anywhere that could be considered as union bashing. I also challenge him, while he is on that journey, to produce all those words with which, like today, I have paid tribute to the trade union movement and to the arbitration movement and have attempted to get to the core of the situation. It is not the clever thing to invoke the tribal war as he is doing. He should keep the tribal war for when he is out in the streets of Brisbane.

SPEECH.PARA: We are trying to get to the bottom of a serious matter, and the serious matter that I am raising today-I raise it with all the personal force I can as John Carrick and as a Liberal-is that all of us have created this grave injustice that exists today. We have all done that by creating and enhancing the tribal war; we in this place having done that no less than any others at all. I repeat that the answer to this is not to wait again for another problem and hit it on the head; it is to understand the whole core of things and get out and tell the people of Australia that they cannot fight each other.

Let me put simply what ought to be asked of the people of Australia: What does a worker on the factory or office floor want? He wants first of all to get a living wage the real purchasing power of which will increase with time so that he can buy more goods and services, and those goods and services should improve in quality not just quantity. So he wants goods and services as cheap as possible and with as much quality as possible. `Oh', say those who oppose that kind of view, `that is antipathetic to the boss'. Hold on-what does the boss want? He wants to manufacture goods and services of as high a quality as possible in as great a quantity as possible for as low a cost as possible and to sell them to the biggest market. Where is that market? The distortion that has been taught in this civil war of ours is a result of the failure to understand that 90 per cent of the market is made up by the ordinary factory and office worker, by the ordinary trade unionist. Indeed the client of the boss is the ordinary trade unionist. They have absolutely identical interests.

I rose to say this with the force I could, not just because we are debating this Bill-it might sound like loud words of rhetoric-but because I believe that, unless this message is told to the people of Australia, day in, day out and week in, week out for the years ahead the living standards of the people of Australia will fall and we will go on using the ugliest of the nineteenth century industrial situation instead of getting on to increased productivity and a higher understanding of human beings. I know nothing that so creates an ugly situation in Australia as the false concept that there is an authentic conflict or polarisation of interests between boss and worker. I know, and it is best that the Australian people know, that their interests are identical. In Japan-where now the cost of maintaining a worker all up is higher than in Australia, so we cannot say we are being beaten by cheap wages-what does a worker do when he goes on strike? He puts on a black armband, stays on the job and works harder. What is he doing? He is registering his protest and at the same time he is saying: `I understand that if I seek to take it out on the boss, I am taking it out on myself'. He does a sensible thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh no!
—`Oh no' says Senator Georges.
—What the employer in Japan does is to go to South Korea or somewhere else to get cheap labour. Don't give us all that rubbish.

—I shall be delighted if Senator Georges rises in his place in due course and debates this matter. I have the greatest admiration for him in his willingness to handle issues but he cannot get away from the fundamental situation. I put it to him that it is wrong to define, develop and exacerbate the concept that there is a polarisation, a complete antipathy of interest, between boss and worker. The solution of this Bill in the long run is that it is right to preach the virtue of co-operation, the virtue of higher real wages, and the virtue of the entrenchment of margins for skill and, wherever possible, for disputes to be sorted out on the factory floor. If that is done, it will be the reason why we shall never see another piece of legislation like this again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel somewhat daunted following the excellent speech by Senator Sir John Carrick. Of course, I disagree with his political philosophies as no doubt he disagrees with mine, but the general thrust of his remarks should be noted by this Parliament, because of the precedents being created by the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration) Bill. What in effect he was saying was that this is a most extraordinary measure for this Parliament to be enacting and that it should be isolated, quarantined, and never be used again. That also came through the remarks of Senator Michael Baume, although not as specifically. Senator Siddons was also of that mind, although the effect of his remarks was perhaps not what he intended at one stage when he mentioned that the Transport Workers Union of Australia was in his view committing industrial mayhem. It may well have been interpreted from his speech that he was inviting this Parliament to use the same methods against that union that it is against the Builders Labourers Federation.
—No, that was not my intention.

—I am glad to hear that Senator Siddons did not intend that to be so. Serious problems are involved in this area and I hope that I will not bore the Senate too greatly by going into some of the technical aspects. I begin at section 143 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Any organisation or person interested, the Minister or the Registrar, may apply to the Court for an order directing the cancellation of the registration of an organisation . . .

That is a function given to the court and is clearly a judicial function. If one looks at the Constitution of this country, under which we have now lived for many years and which in recent days has been highly praised in this chamber, one sees that section 71 reads:

The judicial power of the Commonwealth shall be vested in a Federal Supreme Court, to be called the High Court of Australia, and in such other federal courts as the parliament creates, and in such other courts as it invests with federal jurisdiction. The High Court shall consist of a Chief Justice, and so many other Justices, not less than two, as the Parliament prescribes.

It may be hereafter that the deregistration of this union by way of an Act of Parliament will be looked upon as some sort of administrative act-that because the Parliament can create organisations, it can unmake them. Whether that is so, the fact remains that the deregistration of a union, whether an administrative function or not, can certainly also be a judicial function as is evidenced by section 143 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. That is a matter of grave concern for this Parliament, particularly when the Constitution provides for a separation of powers.
I want now to talk in general terms. The form of the Bill that is now before us is worth reading because it is such a small one. It reads:

Whereas the Parliament considers that it is desirable, in the interest of preserving the system of conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes extending beyond the limits of any one State, to cancel the registration of The Australian Building Construction Employees' and Builders Labourers' Federation under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904:
It goes on:
The registration of The Australian Building Construction Employees' and Builders Labourers' Federation under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 is, by force of this section, cancelled.

There is no preamble to the Bill which gives reason, evidence or argument as to why it should be cancelled. Placitum (xxxv) of section 51 of the Constitution deals with the settlement of industrial disputes beyond any one State. Placitum (xiii) of section 51 provides that whereas Parliament considers that it is appropriate for the proper procedures in banking and the proper running of the banking system of Australia, such and such a bank could be dissolved, and it is by force of that provision dissolved. Therefore, the precedent is set not only in terms of the industrial relations power of the Commonwealth, but in reference to any power of the Commonwealth. That matter should give us concern.

It is comparable to the Bill of Attainder where Parliament, simply through the very Act itself, condemned somebody to death, or to what used to be called the Bills of pains and penalty which in the same way imposed other penalties. It is a matter that should be looked at not simply in terms of its effect upon the industrial relations power of the Commonwealth but in terms of the wider power given to this Parliament. This is why it is heartening that contributors to this debate have expressed their concern. It is apparent that there is great concern about this legislation, as no doubt there was great concern in Cabinet. It is right and proper that that should be the case.

The process of law should apply across the board. It is easy enough to apply the process of law to the beautiful, the admired and the attractive. The real test comes as to whether it can be applied to the ugly, the terrible and the unattractive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis.

—No, Senator Lewis has some very attractive features! After a year in this place I have come to the view that the ability of parliamentarians is much higher than the media and public recognise. Therefore, when this sort of Bill is brought before the House consideration must be given to the fact that it has been brought before it by people of high integrity, people who are sensible, and that therefore great regard should be paid to it. At the same time when one looks at the radical nature of the Bill-as Senator Sir John Carrick said, it is unique, and other speakers may be able to tell whether it is in fact unique-and at the ramifications of the Bill, not simply in terms of the industrial relations powers of the Commonwealth but all the powers, one must pause and consider whether the better way to proceed, if at all possible, is by way of judicial process. I think it is important to put on the record, as people already have put on the record, the concern that all parliamentarians from the various parties have had about this matter forming, as I said before, a precedent for the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Michael Baume spoke about the solidarity of Caucus. He said that members of the Liberal Party of Australia have a right to express views, and that may well be so. They have certainly shown over the years a commendable ability to agree in this chamber. I do not wish to go into tribal warfare about this, except to say that when one looks at the procedures, the structures and the instruments by which political power is carried on one finds that it is necessary, given the nature of Government these days, to create an ability for an Executive to be able to proceed on the assurance that it will be able to govern securely. It is proper, therefore, that an Executive should come into parliament with confidence, knowing that the Party from which it is drawn will support it. Indeed, I think that is an approach that is taken right across the board, as is demonstrated, in contrast to what the theory might be, by the evidence that the Executives of both parties are able to do this. Whether that is good in all situations is another matter but certainly it is the way the present system runs.

There have been allegations made about a union, the people in it and their reputations. As the Bills are drawn and have come before the Parliament, there is no evidence on the basis of which Parliament is able to exercise what is in effect, a judicial function. That is a matter which Senator Tate touched upon and which I will not repeat.

I rose simply to express those thoughts so that when people come to read Hansard and look at this period in times hereafter it will not appear that this radical procedure, as Senator Sir John Carrick properly called it, was taken lightly but that there were people on all sides of the House who, as parliamentarians, were concerned about the procedures adopted and about Executive power, and that this quite historic and unique debate was one which concerned high issues, that people were concerned about those high issues and that these decisions were not taken without considerable anguish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration) Bill 1986 cognately with the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration-Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986 because one Bill is consequential upon the other. While the Labor Government would have us believe that this legislation is designed to remove the Builders Labourers Federation from the industrial scene, the truth of the matter can be found elsewhere. The truth, of course, is that the BLF will still be able to function and negotiate with employers, employees and other unions, provided that the employers and the other unions are prepared to negotiate with it. The history of this union is such that that is highly probable.
—You are quite right. The whole situation is impossible and this legislation is a waste of time.

—It is not a waste of time. Frankly, I question the motives, but I do not question the effect. In my view, the effect will be negligible. I do not know whether it is a sop to the Left or it is inadequate legislation by design or ineptitude. The truth of the matter is that under this legislation the BLF will continue to function in the way it has in the past. The only deprivation it will suffer is that it will no longer be a body recognised by and able to appear before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That, to me, is the simple limitation.

SPEECH.PARA: It ought not to be forgotten that the legislation before us in no way seeks to deal with the $4.5m to $5m of assets that the union presently has. One accepts that that is primarily a State matter, but the Federal Government does have jurisdiction over the Australian Capital Territory and, if it was serious about the distribution of those funds back to union members, it could provide legislation accordingly. It ought not to be forgotten that this union has a capacity--

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be a waste of time. Possibly the funds are somewhere else now-the State branches.

—Senator Georges said, to take up his interjection, that the funds are elsewhere. Obviously, they have been spirited away. I understand that Norm Gallagher has been walking around with a big handbag with $1.5m in cash in it. I am sure he is not going off to some exotic--
—You would be doing the same if you were under the same threat.

—I would not be conducting, in such a capricious and irresponsible way, the handling of funds of a union of that type, but of course, I would not be in a union of that type. It ought to be remembered that this union is subject to receipts by way of contributions of something like $6m a year. That makes it a pretty potent and pretty powerful union. Unions are not necessarily strong by virtue of their numbers; they are strong by virtue of their revenue and the strategic position they have in the work force. More importantly, there has been no indication from the Federal Government that it intends to enter into discussions or negotiations with the State Government for complementary legislation to be introduced for the distribution by the States for the funds of the various State branches of the union.
—That will take 10 years to achieve.

—That will never be done. As somebody said the other day, it is a wonder we ever got to federation. I might say that it was no thanks to Western Australia. It was only the gold miners who came across from Victoria who carried the day. The goldfield vote in Western Australia got us into federation, thanks to Victorians.
—We cannot even get a Bill of Rights through this place.

—I am not sorry about that, I must say to Senator Georges. As a result of those assets and enormous receipts, the union will be able to flourish and grow. Perhaps the clearest indication of the Government's lack of commitment to the demise of the BLF can be found in the provisions that allow for its resuscitation and its resurrection in three years time. For the time being, and I am not sure that is going to happen, if it seeks to be dormant and to retain its membership and its finances, it can come back in three years time in the same clothes with the same union leaders, conduct itself in the same way, indulge itself in the same activities and create havoc in the community, as it has done for the last 10 years. To me that is an absurd caveat to place upon this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps we ought to look at the history of the union. It was first deregistered in 1974 for a period of two years-not three years-and for what reasons? The same reasons as it is again being deregistered. For the reasons, deregistration proceedings were undertaken in 1981 by the Honourable Andrew Peacock, the then Minister for Industrial Relations in the Fraser Government. For the same reasons, legislation was introduced in 1985 to commence proceedings as a result of a determination of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Yet I still do not understand-no doubt Senator Georges will be able to explain to me later-the deficiencies and the defects in that legislation which prevent the deregistration axiomatic upon the decision of the Arbitration Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is impossible to legislate in this field.

—Legislation was passed. Was the legislation defective? Was the Government incompetent or did it not have the will? Why do we have this piece of legislation when the last piece of legislation tells us that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations can make application before the courts for deregistration.
—You would have to be stupid; that is why.
—Senator Georges says that the Government is stupid.
—I said that we are all stupid.
—I am sure that on your side, Senator, that is probably a pretty universal view.
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, will you pass your remarks through the Chair instead of holding a private conversation with Senator Georges.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I always find conversations with Senator Georges both stimulating and rewarding. I remind the Senate of what the deregistration proceedings of 1974 found. It was:

SPEECH.PARA: The evidence established that in the years 1970, 1971, 1972, 1973 and 1974, the organisation by its officers, organisers, delegates and representatives has continually called stoppages of work and strikes, and often without providing management with any prior opportunity for discussing claims made and often making fresh on-the-spot claims as soon as claims which had been made were granted. It has held up jobs by banning overtime, by placing bans on jobs, by preventing work being done, by preventing equipment-for example cranes-from being used and by expanding bans from one building job to other building jobs controlled and operated by the same building contractor, such expansion being characterised by the president of the organisation as `blowing them sky-high'.

It has disregarded the process of conciliation and arbitration, either by ignoring it altogether, or refusing to accept decisions made or rulings given or denying agreements made in the course of the process, or repudiating them as soon as they were made and claiming that they were not binding. Even where claims were made which were novel in the industry, rather than go to arbitration on them the organisation has completely closed down the site and the job with a view to forcing the building contractor to meet the claim. Leaders of the organisation have jeered at the notion of obeying the law, awards and agreements, and the organisation has openly flouted all three.
I continue with the findings:

Many of the stoppages and strikes it has brought about have lasted for months and a number have continued indefinitely and are still current. Large industrial jobs have been held up for lengthy periods, causing losses amounting in all to millions of dollars, which hardly brings about industrial goodwill. Jobs have been left in an unsafe state so that they are likely to collapse, which likewise does not promote goodwill in industry.
This document goes on to explain all the activities which are still being undertaken. It talks about attempts which have been made:

. . . to make employers dismiss men whom they did not wish to dismiss, but who were not satisfactory to the organisation, to make them accept labour provided by the organisation, and on the organisation's terms, instead of choosing their employees and when they have chosen them continuing to employ them. The organisation has insisted on the reinstatement of men dismissed for good cause, including disobedience and irresponsibility, and pay has been demanded for men on strike and for work which has not been carried out. All these have been conditions of return to work and bans being called off or of stoppages and bans not being placed on a job or part of a job. Men, when compulsorily reinstated through the union's insistence, often cause trouble and can only then be got rid of by management coming to special arrangements with the union to buy them off.
They are the sorts of things about which we read in contemporary times. But we are now talking about 1974. The findings continued:
There has been intimidation by the respondent-
the respondent being the BLF-

on job sites on a wholesale basis. The organisation has been guilty of sabotage on these sites and has taken part in mob violence causing destruction on industrial sites and the disruption of industrial projects. When it has suited them, union leaders have led their members in numbers upon invasions of industrial sites, doing considerable damage there and preventing work taking place and occasioning great hostility and bitterness in the industry. On occasions, police have been called upon to deal with the situation which has arisen.

The respondents have claimed, of course, that it is not a matter in which the police ought to be involving themselves. So it goes on. It says that attempts at reconciliation and arbitration have failed. The respondents have made it quite clear in respect of settlements that it makes no difference to tell the respondent that statements and agreements it has made and entered into are expected to be honoured; it just simply does not honour them. One could go through this document at length, but I shall not do so other than to tell the Senate that:
In addition, it is apparent that the executive officers of the union-
and there is no provision in this legislation to prevent the union office-bearers from holding office in the future--

have endeavoured to establish an unreasonable domination of employers and indeed of employees by intimidatory actions, arrogant, vulgar and insulting communications, mass violence to property, and menaces, sometimes in mass, and sometimes terrifying to persons.

It gives a particular example of the type of threats that could be expected from the union at that time. It is interesting to note that during this deregistration period, the union flourished. Its membership numbers rose between 1974 and 1976, because that legislation was defective. It was the same type of legislation as we have before us now. It was superficial, and it allowed the union, superficially, to be dormant. But of course, it was not dormant; it carried on regardless, with greater vitality and strength, and greater dominance and greater menace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Greater solidarity-that is what you are doing at present.
—Senator Georges says: `By solidarity'.
—Greater solidarity; it was under threat.

—The evidence that has been given so far in the court proceedings is that it is intimidation; solidarity brought about by intimidation. In other words, if a man is not part of a union, he is in big trouble. Let us go a little further. It is interesting to note that during that period, as I say, the union flourished. On 16 July 1976, after a further lengthy hearing, the Industrial Registrar restored the organisation to the register and, in so doing, he said exactly this:

SPEECH.PARA: The community is entitled to be assured that the BLF accepts the duties and liabilities which accompany the rights and privileges which flow from registration. In my opinion, the BLF has satisfied the heavy onus resting upon an applicant when it applies for registration after having had that registration cancelled by the court. I am satisfied that registration is sought to assist in achieving the primary purposes of the Act: the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by conciliation and arbitration; and that the Federation will use all its influence to induce its members to accept the outcome of the function of the tribunals created by the Act.
A major consideration for the Registrar reregistering the union was a Council resolution unanimously followed on 1 June 1976. It says in part:

This application for reregistration is made for the purpose of regaining for the Federation the status of a registered organisation and thereby enabling it to participate fully in the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by conciliation and, where necessary, by arbitration. It is further desired that there be again available to the Federation the machinery contained in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act for encouragement of the democratic control of registered organisations and the full participation by its members in the affairs of the Federation. It is understood that the privileges which attach to the status of a registered organisation carry with them corresponding duties and responsibilities to further the achievement of the objectives of the Act and, in particular, to utilise the means provided by the Act for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes and fully observe the letter and spirit of awards and agreements made by or under the auspices of the Commission. Such duties also require the officers of an organisation to work to minimise direct industrial action.

The Federal Council is accurately aware that failure to discharge such duties and responsibilities or otherwise to give effect to this undertaking could lead to the Federation again being deregistered and so render abortive the time, effort and costs which have been expended by the present application.

That is the reason that the union gives for wanting to be reregistered-to give it a chance to be involved in the environment of goodwill, peace, settlement, conciliation and arbitration. No sooner had this reregistration taken place than we saw the real character, the real opening and the real soul of the union movement, and its real intentions. In November 1976, the very same year that the union was reregistered, Mr Gallagher, the General Secretary, told the Federal Council that the Federation `should devise new tactics which will hurt the boss'.

Mr Black reiterated those words later and he gave his views on how to deal with the boss. I remind honourable senators that this is in the same year and within months of the BLF being reregistered. Mr Black said:

These tactics the delegates have suggested are all designed to disrupt and cause the boss as much loss of production as possible. This is a good thing. They are part of our overall strategy of using guerilla tactics instead of the all-out strike weapon used in the past, where members went out on lengthy strikes. These tactics are designed to hurt the boss in the pocket rather than to hurt ourselves in the pocket.

Getting down to basics, what we mean by guerilla tactics is to blind the boss with science. The use of stop-work meetings, 1/2 day stoppages, bans and limitations, the use of the safety code, concrete bans and rumours are all designed to disrupt the boss's production.
Mr Black went on to say:

I believe, even though the Federation has given guarantees not to break concrete pours to get registered again, we should still make the concrete the main battering ram against the bosses. In November last year at the Federal Council, Gallagher said we should devise new tactics with which to hurt the Boss. He said there was a new ball game now. By this he meant the Federation's argeement not to break concrete pours.
That was part of the agreement. This is the BLF's new tactic. Mr Black said:

. . . we have to find new ways of struggle and new forms of tactics. By this, we mean for example that we should stop the concrete before it actually is poured. There is no agreement on this. We can have a lightning stoppage, on the job, ask the boss for the $30 site allowance. If he refuses we can tell him we are not pouring concrete today, but possibly the next day.

In other words, the spirit of the agreement, the body of the law, its intention, thrust and objectives, were never uppermost in the mind of the BLF. They were hindrances and the BLF was looking for new ways to overcome them. As I have said, it ought to be remembered that this kind of conduct and activity took place immediately following deregistration; it took place immediately following two years of previous deregistration. Need one look further for proof of the real intent of the BLF? Its conduct was such that, in 1981, the Hon. Andrew Peacock, the then responsible Minister, instituted deregistration proceedings with the full support at that time of the building industry. However, upon coming to government the Australian Labor Party withdrew from the deregistration proceedings. This left the employers in a very invidious situation. It left them absolutely high and dry and they, too, subsequently had to withdraw. The Government discontinued its proceedings in February 1984 after the BLF had given a written undertaking, which the Minister accepted in a statement to the court in December 1983. At that time the Master Builders Association declined to accept the offer but subsequently it also withdrew in 1984. But a pre-condition of its withdrawing was the signing of the Building Industry Agreement 1984-86. I will not go through it all but it really very much reflects the hypocritical statement that was made in 1976 when the union was seeking registration. The first part of that agreement states:
The intention of the parties is that this agreement is designed to place the maximum emphasis on the peaceful settlement of disputes.

The agreement goes on to list a whole range of things but the general thrust of it is that there should be very little unilateral industrial action and there shall be a dispute settling process without direct action. However, the irony is that there was very considerable industrial unrest by the union in April 1984, admittedly following the Minister withdrawing from the proceedings, but prior to the union's withdrawing in July of that year. No sooner had that agreement been signed than the BLF began its guerrilla tactics again. In October, the very month that the agreement was signed, the BLF undertook industrial action for a 36-hour week, completely contrary to the agreement it had made that it would not proceed past a 38-hour week. This was followed by a campaign to increase award wages by 2.6 per cent in spite of the agreement. This was then followed by the Melbourne Cricket Ground light towers demarcation dispute. That, in turn, was followed by the Kurri Kurri dispute, which was followed by the Sydney Police Centre dispute. It should be remembered that all this industrial disruption by the BLF was taking place in 1984, the very same year in which the deregistration proceedings had been withdrawn by the BLF and the BLF had signed its peace agreement. On 4 April 1986, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission found:

The evidence in these proceedings disclosed that during the period 1982-1985, the industrial relations policy which the Federation adopted and applied immediately after being registered in 1976 continued to dominate its activities.

This, of course, was the period of the deregistration proceedings, the BLF's subsequent withdrawal and the period after which the union signed its peace agreement. Let me just remind honourable senators very quickly of what that agreement contains in part. It contains a provision for no industrial disruption and no variation to the award; proposed new allowances and any increases in existing allowances will become a commitment only to the extent that they are ratified by the Commission or by the appropriate State tribunal. In December 1983 the Minister accepted that undertaking and we saw in a few months an industrial campaign for a $9 a week increase. This disruption was going on in the very same year in spite of the BLF's previous undertakings. There is a whole litany of activity which time prevents me from quoting but the BLF immediately undertook further guerrilla tactics.

Perhaps at this point we ought really to be looking at the activities that the BLF undertakes. There are a whole range of activities that the union undertakes that are designed to provide for the maximum disruption to concrete pouring. It entails walking off the job without notice, demanding that certain employees be employed and that those who are dismissed for quite legitimate reasons be reinstated. These tactics are all of a guerrilla nature and are designed to ensure the maximum discomfort to and dislocation of the industry. Sadly, that is the history of the BLF. There are a whole range of other matters of conduct which I cannot lay my hands on at the moment, but these are the general style activities of the BLF. We ought not to forget the activities in Western Australia, a Labor Government State, where there has been no deregistration. One might well ask why that is so. Of course, the government of the day, led by Premier Burke, receives very considerable support from the BLF as part of its power base.

TALK.START.PARA: —And from the electorate, Senator.

—He gets some support from the electorate. One puts it down to a temporary aberration on the part of the electors. I have no doubt that they will see the light in due course and repent. We will forgive them their sins and, no doubt, they will return the Liberal Party to its proper status and its proper place in the community and, that is, in government.
—I thought you must have masterminded the Opposition's campaign as it did so well.

—I am tempted to respond to the interjection but I will simply say that I thought we did remarkably well. We were doing very badly until I came along and made my modest contribution. I am not ashamed of our result after the polls of previous weeks. But, of course, Mr Burke has declined to indulge himself in the deregistration proceedings; that is the farce of this legislation. If there is no deregistration in the States, it makes this legislation an absolute failure, a eunuch. Quite obviously, all of those who are presently registered under a Federal award will seek registration under a State award. It will be a very cosy little arrangement in Western Australia where Mr Burke will take them unto his bosom and ensure that they are able to continue to conduct themselves in the way that they have been doing, using their guerrilla tactics, creating havoc, causing disruption and distortion throughout the industry. The various employers will be subject to that blackmail because they will have no recourse to the courts. As happened in 1984, the moment the employers take the union to court for deregistration, the Federal Government will withdraw. The employers, who had signed statutory declarations and given verbal commitments, would then be subject to enormous intimidation and disruption as a result of their courage; for their sins they would be singled out. It is no wonder that employers are reluctant to go ahead when they have a weak-kneed vacillating government that will allow such things.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation will have absolutely no effect because there is no commitment. If this Government were serious, it would have sought complementary legislation from the States. But it has not; it has not even negotiated with the States for the distribution of the assets of the BLF back to its members. As I said at the outset, there is no prospect that in any way this legislation will change the character, the style or the conduct of the BLF. The BLF continues to negotiate with employers, it continues to negotiate with other unions and it will continue to proceed in the way that it has been doing. The only disadvantage that it now has is that it cannot go before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. But, if it were to take a leaf out of Robert Holmes a Court's book, it would look for a nice compliant union of similar character and just simply take it over. Of course, there is a provision whereby unions can refuse membership, but, if the BLF could find a union, such as the joiners, carpenters and fitters union, whatever its exact description is--

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not matter from your point of view.

—No, it does not matter. Whatever it is called, the BLF could take it over or amalgamate with it and could carry on under a different name but with the same union leaders. Norm Gallagher could do the same as Robert Holmes a Court; he could do a takeover. He has the assets of his own union and could conduct himself as he is doing now and nothing could stop him. So in my view this legislation is a fraud.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that Senator Crichton-Browne has been cut short by time because he has made a good case against the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration) Bill 1985 and the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration-Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986. He has shown quite forcefully and with quite substantial evidentiary support that this legislation will not be effective. If we pass legislation through this House, we should be certain that it will have some effectiveness.
—That is right; it should not be a charade or a facade.

—It is a facade; it is a charade. I recall that we previously passed through this House legislation in connection with the electricity crisis in Queensland. We passed that legislation through this House to accelerate the Federal coverage of that union. Of course, what happened was that it was challenged, which delayed the normal processes of Federal coverage rather than assist them, and the legislation was thrown out by the High Court of Australia. As a result, the 1,000 workers who were so arbitrarily dismissed by the Queensland Government through a variety of means remain dismissed. A substantial number of them are still unemployed and have become unemployable in Queensland because of the actions of that Government in refusing them employment in the only industry in which they have a skill. By the legislation that we passed through here, we assisted in what one could consider to be the greatest betrayal of a group of workers in Australian union and industrial relations history. Surely, we should reflect on that and realise that we cannot by legislation settle an industrial dispute, especially when we have established forums to which we have given the responsibility to act in these matters. I consider this legislation to be an interference. It might be justified if it were successful but it is inevitable that it will fail in reality, as Senator Crichton-Browne pointed out.

SPEECH.PARA: By interjection, I stirred Senator Sir John Carrick, a man of great passion, to ever greater passion. I was moved to do that but in perhaps the opposite direction that he intended. He is always sincere. He has hopes but they are unreal. In the climate of the work place, the worker appreciates that he has to protect himself, by whatever means available through his union and association, by decision on the floor, from the decision of the employer. Senator Sir John Carrick said that the employer is a person of great integrity--

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not. I said that there were faults on both sides.
—Right. I was going to amend that and say that in most cases, which is possibly what he did mean, that is so.
—I placed the blame on neither side.

—Well, from what he said I inferred that that was the case. Of course, the situation is that in many cases the employer shows as much loyalty and consideration to his employee as sometimes a general is forced to do, that is, to close his mind to the needs of those over whom he has some supervisional control. The climate in which the worker works in Australia at present is one in which there is a substantial level of irresponsibility on the part of those who control the companies. If anyone wants evidence of that, they can look at what happened yesterday and today when there was a great enhancement of someone's personal wealth through transactions on the Stock Exchange to the disadvantage of everyone employed in that industry. Not one extra bar of steel has been produced by Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd as a result of these massive transactions that will give great wealth to some men.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick spoke of Japan. I say to him that the Japanese worker has a problem. Perhaps by tradition the Japanese worker shows great restraint. But what is the result of that restraint? The Japanese employer is seeking to obtain the cheapest labour possible, in consequence Japanese employers have gone off-shore-that is the popular term-to South Korea, Taiwan and a number of other places to obtain cheap labour against the interest of their workers. That will have an impact in due course.

What I object to about this legislation, and Senator Sir John Carrick's approach to it, is that it will do the very opposite of what is intended. Senator Sir John Carrick talked about civil war; he used that term time and again; he used the word `jungle'. This legislation will increase that possibility. Its faults and limitations have been pointed out by others. What we will do with this legislation will be to create in the work place a highly destructive situation which will lead to the erosion of the conciliation and arbitration process. What will happen in the work place? This attempt to deregister the BLF will, as the leaders of the BLF have said, force builders labourers into contract-type arrangements. That is what they have been doing up to this point and that is what we have been complaining about. They are the methods they have used to obtain the best result. So what we are really doing with this legislation is accelerating that process. We are concerned about a jungle in the work place, but if this legislation is passed we are creating another jungle. However, it will not succeed.

I have a personal complaint to make about this legislation. As a member of the Australian Labor Party I complain when the Labor Party follows a path to deregister a union. It is doing so in spite of advice that if it once stepped foot upon that path it would have to do all the things a conservative government would need to do and would do. That is what this Labor Government, of which I am a member, is doing at present. It is doing all those things because once it made the first decision it had to take all the initiatives--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—That is why there is so much horse-laughing from the Opposition benches.
—How did you vote, Georgie?

—Let me develop my thoughts at present. The Labor Government has followed that path. I believe that the Victorian State Labor Government has followed an aggressive path through the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Crabb. It has shown no experience of the work place, no understanding of conciliation and no understanding of the system. It merely has provoked and aggravated the situation rather than seeking a solution other than by legislation which is bound to fail. This Government has followed the same path. I can say only that its actions have been equally pathetic. Once we start along the path of deregistration and want to make it effective in this sort of circumstance we have to take every step to do so. The only way to make this legislation effective is to apply further sanctions. But, if we are to succeed in what we are doing, we can apply further sanctions only of the type that Bjelke-Petersen has followed in Queensland-sanctions, if I may say so, which would mean the imprisonment of all those who are likely to lead the BLF.
—Shoot them!

—Of course; take those further necessary steps, to make this legislation succeed, which only a military dictatorship would take-steps either to imprison the leaders or in some way to exclude them from the scene. I find that absolutely unacceptable as an initiative taken by a Labor government. I have been through this before. The previous time the legislation came before this place I spoke against it. I did the sneaky thing of abstaining from voting on it. But let me make it clear to honourable senators on this occasion: I have been in the Labor Party and associated with the trade union movement for the last 40 years but I have not reached a point in my career where I have to support the deregistration of a union. So I put on the record right now that I intend to vote against the legislation. I make that clear. If there is no division I intend to ask that my vote be recorded.
—Very courageous.
—It has nothing to do with courage.
—Is it stupid, then?
—It could be.
—Are you offering yourself for pre-selection again?

—No, and I was about to say so. If the honourable senator were to say to me that at this stage I ought not to take the position that I am taking because it is easy for me to take it, being in my last term, I would say that it is more difficult now to take that position than if I were facing endorsement on the next occasion. Let me say to Senator Walsh-he seems to be able to apply his conscience to and impose his will on everyone else because he is in a position of power to do so-that he ought not to be imposing on someone such as me the expectation that I will vote against a long tradition of the Party, against my own principles and position because I am free of having to seek an endorsement on the next occasion. I am not going to leave this place with this sort of decision on my conscience. I hope to have a few more useful years to do the things I want to do within the Labor movement. But it has reached the point where it is not possible to do so within the Labor movement and maintain my own principles and those of the Labor movement if the Labor Party is to persist with legislation of this sort. It is an outrage as far as I am concerned. I am going to take a position and a stand against the outrage, no matter what the consequences may be.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the sort of implication Senator Walsh wants to place on what I do, he can do so. He has made implications about others which are equally hollow. I suggest to Senator Walsh that my record in the Labor movement is equal to his. Because it is equal to his, what I intend to do is not easy at all, whether or not I face endorsement this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you get expelled?

—That has nothing to do with the question before the chamber at present. Members of the Labor Party have to face up to the consequences of what they do, as individuals and as a group. The Party cannot persist in drifting away from policy, from its rank and file, without seams starting to appear and to widen.
—Georgie, why won't you agree that there must be co-operation between management and workers to get success in this nation? It is not a matter of confrontation.

—I do not disagree with what the honourable senator says, but let us take a look at the record of the BLF in Queensland. There has hardly been a dispute in Queensland between the BLF and employers. I suppose that one of the areas of greatest growth in the building industry is Queensland. What is the honourable senator saying to me-that the abuse is an argument against improper use? We are taking initiatives and putting through legislation that looks only at the abuses? It does not look at the proper use of union responsibility and leadership and employer management. If the Government looked at the good and forgot about the bad it would realise the damage which this legislation is going to do. The only way that this legislation can be made effective is if the States can be forced, by some means or other, to take deregistration proceedings against the union in every State.

SPEECH.PARA: Does this Government intend to deregister the BLF in Queensland? Is it to impose upon those who are in a position to do something about it the deregistration of the BLF in Queensland? What a grave injustice that would be in Queensland. What a grave injustice that would be in South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania. Why should the BLF in Queensland cop the responsibility for the union's mismanagement in Victoria and New South Wales? If there have been errors or acts that are not acceptable, if there has been the breaking of the law, there are processes by which that can be dealt with. If law enforcement bodies in New South Wales and Victoria are so poor that they cannot bring to account a breaking of the law by a union member, a union or anyone else, we ought to be looking at the law enforcement capacities of those two States. We should not start passing legislation which is absolutely contrary to the rights of individuals. It should not be passed here for expediency. Yet honourable senators opposite will pass it and be responsible for it. What is more, they will try to improve it by making the period 10 years. They cannot improve the legislation.

On the Government side there are many people who feel the same way as I, and they have my sympathy. But they may be restrained for the reasons that Senator Walsh has indicated, and I do not blame them because they have to measure and balance what is in the best interests of what they want to do. As far as I am concerned, as Senator Walsh has indicated, I am not restrained. I find it harder for that reason. The legislation ought not to have been initiated. It should never have been brought before the House of Representatives and the Senate.

This legislation ought to be rejected and those who are under some constraints in the community because of the actions of the BLF should go through the normal processes, using the forums that have been established. It is said that they do not have the courage to do so. Let them get the courage. Let us not put through this Senate legislation which takes away the rights of individuals and organisations to participate in the work place. That is virtually what we are doing. I get back to what I said previously. Because there is abuse does not mean that the various existing institutions should not be used to solve the problem with the BLF.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition to the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration) Bill and the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration-Consequential Provisions) Bill has been of two types. The first has been from those who are either ignorant or wilful misleaders, of whom Senator Crichton-Browne is the prime example, who have asserted that this legislation will be ineffective because the Builders Labourers Federation can continue to exist in State branches. Even Senator Crichton-Browne ought to know that the Commonwealth does not have the constitutional power to deregister State branches. New South Wales and Victorian legislation to deregister State branches of the BLF-the State registered union-has either been passed or is about to be passed so that the BLF will cease to exist as State institutions in those States. He also ignored the fact that other States have the power, should they deem it necessary, to take similar action. Queensland, a non-Labor Government, has decided not to do so. His comments were highly misleading.

SPEECH.PARA: The second qualitative type of opposition is that which came from ivory tower lawyers and their acolytes, the sorts of people who have a vision which, like many visions, is based on an hallucination of a perfect world when dealing with such things as civil liberties in the perfect world and the protection of those civil liberties. The trouble with that is that we do not have a perfect world. It ignores the fact that pursuit of the objectives of a perfect world ignores, bypasses and fails to achieve the best actual outcomes, which is more important than whatever hallucinatory visions they might have. In the real world the adoption of that sort of attitude preserves the liberty, in this case of the BLF national leadership, to welsh on agreements, not just with employers, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and governments, but with fellow unionists. That is a practice which it has followed habitually for more than a decade.

The BLF has a national leadership with a history of violent assault on individuals in an attempt to enforce its objectives. That outcome has been achieved. It would continue to exist if the visions of the civil libertarian purists were to be adopted as policy. I suggest that such people-I know that some of them sincerely believe this and I accept that-should consult, for example, the Millian liberal-naturally small `l' liberal-limit to personal liberty, which generally goes along the lines that people are free to do what they wish and should be free to do so, and the State should not interfere with what people do, provided that in the exercise of that individual liberty they do not infringe upon the liberties of others.

I will not attempt to deal with the criticisms that have been made about all aspects of the Bills but I shall deal briefly with a few of them. Senator Lewis, among others, asked what the Government intends to do about the assets of the organisation. I am sure that Senator Lewis would know that only in the Australian Capital Territory does the Commonwealth Government have control.
