TALK.START.PARA: —Are you asking Mr Cain and Mr Wran to do anything about it?

—I thought that the honourable senator went along with the general policy of his Party; that is, what is State business should be left to the States. I do not know. I have not asked either of them and I do not know whether anybody else has. I would not presume to teach them how to suck eggs. They would both be well aware, as would the governments that they lead, of the possible need to do that. An important question was asked about what is to be done about the possibility of the BLF taking over other unions. A relatively small union in Victoria has been cited. The answer, Senator Lewis, is that that union could take over the work functions performed by BLF members only if a State or Commonwealth arbitration commission gave it the work coverage.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the terms of the second Bill before the Senate today, the Government will take action which no previous government has attempted to take to reallocate the existing areas of work coverage provided under Commonwealth legislation for BLF members. That leads us to the critical distinction between this legislation and the actions of the Fraser Government, which proposed deregistration, a proposal which was on the table for two years without anything happening and which would have remained on the table for very much longer. Even then, it might well have been ineffective because the BLF has been deregistered in the past without apparently making a great deal of difference to the way that it operated. What this Government is doing, which is unique, is that, as well as deregistering the organisation federally, it is making provision for regulations which will enable other unions to take over BLF work coverage and therefore secure for people employed in the industry the benefits of responsible participation in the Federal system and the benefits of Federal awards.

I understand that the Australian Democrats and the Opposition have forecast an intention to move amendments to extend from three years to five and 10 years respectively the period, regardless of whatever remnants of the BLF may survive in particular States, in which it may make another application for registration under the Federal Act. An appropriate period involves an element of judgment. The Government chose three years because that was judged to be a completely adequate time for the new arrangements as to work coverage by other unions to be settled and bedded down.

It also must be realised that the registration process is slow. A contested registration application would take two or three years which would be on top of the threshold hearing which could be expected to last at least four months. So the Government's proposition effectively prevents reregistration, even if the Commission were agreeable to registering the Federation, for a period of six years. That is judged by the Government to be enough. It is a question of judgment as to whether that period should be longer or even shorter. If remnants of the BLF in those States where it has a more responsible record than it has had in the south-east of the mainland continue to exist-in some States they probably will-it seems to the Government that it is not entirely fair to deny those sections of the existing organisation the privilege, or at least the possibility of reregistration under the Commonwealth Act.

I understand that Senator Siddons has acknowledged that 10 years is too long. If he reflects on what I have said that is, that the effective period between now and when the remnants of an organisation could be actually reregistered is probably six years and possibly longer, he might come to the conclusion that the provision in the legislation of three years as a period before a reregistration application or preliminary hearings could even start, is adequate.

Immediately following the BLFs deregistration in 1974 it continued industrial disruption. Upon its reregistration in 1976 it showed no inclination of repenting. SPEECH.PARA: In 1981 when the Fraser Government commenced proceedings for deregistration of the BLF it in no way tempered its style of approach to industrial relations. In 1984 when the deregistration proceedings were withdrawn-firstly in February by the Government, at the request of the Minister, as I recall, and then in July of the same year, when the Master Builders Association withdrew its proceedings-the Federation continued to conduct its normal capricious, irresponsible guerrilla tactics. In fact we now have a situation where it is intimidating employers in the Australian Capital Territory and demanding, in the event it is deregistered, that they continue to negotiate with it. To that extent the BLF is now black-banning sites and demanding the signing of a letter of agreement to continue to deal with officials of the BLF in relation to industrial matters, whether it be deregistered or otherwise. That guerrilla tactic will continue until such time, under duress, the employers sign a letter accordingly. It is interesting that the Trades and Labour Council of the Australian Capital Territory at a meeting on 7 August 1985 endorsed that type of activity.

In referring to this case it is pertinent to reflect for a moment on the union's activities and why it wreaks such havoc upon the community. The Builders Labourers Federation applies total bans, which means a total withdrawal of labour on a project. Although used on occasions, that tactic has been largely replaced by selective bans. This of course maximises disruption but minimises loss of earnings. It applies the principle of one out, all out in relation to safety issues. If there is a safety issue affecting one employee, all the employees will walk out. It also applies the one on, all on principle so that in the event of inclement weather and only a number of employees being able to be gainfully engaged, it insists that they all be paid irrespective of whether or not their work is carried out.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't mentioned the homers.

Terms of settlement invariably include claims for payment for all time lost, including the time over which the claims have remained unresolved.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course the union's favourite and most devastating trick is that of breaking concrete pours. In the midst of the process of pouring the members stop, and that concrete then has to be broken up by jackhammers. That requires the employment of a number of people and it may well take a full day to lift that concrete and commence the procedure again. Not only is it time consuming and expensive but also it is very costly to the employer in terms of the project being put back further. That has flow on effects in terms of rent, tenancy and all the other ramifications. Of course members of the BLF have this remarkable capacity for demarcation disputes, which was demonstrated in its most graphic and barren form in respect of the lighting of the Melbourne Cricket Ground. After a decision that the job ought not be theirs, they had pickets and intimidated the other employees. The harassed those other employees and their wives, having talked about sexual activity against those wives, and generally acted as complete and absolute thugs. They are just some of the activities that BLF members take delight in engaging in, and for these reasons one can only draw the conclusion that they are not about to be born-again decent, honest, respectable and reasonable employees who are prepared to act as responsible union members within the community.

The sad thing, as Senator Sir John Carrick said, is that the view is often put that the Liberal Party is opposed to unions. I am a great supporter of unions. What distresses me so often is that the responsible people in the work force do not involve themselves in union management and leadership. If they did I am quite sure we would have an industrial relations system much different from that we have at present. Unfortunately these moderate types tend to sit back and the activists and thugs end up controlling the unions. Of course the other workers are then subject to intimidation and threat and are coerced into participating in industrial unrest and strife which, if there were a secret ballot, they would in no way be a party to. For those reasons it is my view that the 10-year period provides the best prospect of ensuring that the Builders Labourers Federation will not reappear.

Having said that, I acknowledge what has been said earlier. I have had some concern in my own mind that this legislation was introduced at a time when the BLF was seeking to appeal to the High Court of Australia. The conflict in my mind was that it was being denied an opportunity to exhaust the judicial processes available to any citizen. This is the one disturbing feature about this legislation but that is balanced out by the Federation's conduct. One could perhaps find extenuating circumstances but the problem with extenuating circumstances is that one tends from time to time to compromise one's fundamental principles. It disturbs me that this legislation is being introduced and rushed through this Parliament, so denying the Builders Labourers Federation an opportunity to exhaust fully the judicial processes available to it within this country. However, for all the reasons I have mentioned I support Senator Lewis's amendment, which to me is an obvious amendment if we are serious about deregistration in its proper form.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CAR IMPORTS: ALLEGED CUSTOMS DUTY FRAUD

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of a report in a recent edition of the National Times referring to alleged Customs duty fraud in the car importing industry-but potentially involving all industries in Australia-that could cost the Government as much as the bottom of the harbour tax schemes? If so, what is the Government doing to tighten import duty requirements and to prevent such fraudulent practices as those alleged to have been carried out by one of Australia's biggest car importers, LNC Industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of valuation for duty is a problem with all the Customs services throughout the world. I understand from the relatively recent Customs Co-operation Council that that issue was discussed and concern was expressed about it by a number of Customs services throughout the world. In respect of the question of valuation for duty of motor cars and an article that appeared in the National Times to which Senator Bolkus referred, an investigation was begun in January 1986, when some irregularities were found in documents used by an importer to enter vehicles. Since that time, a very large number of company documents have been examined during the investigation and demands for additional duty totalling $2.1m have been made on the importer under the provisions of the Customs Act that refer to the recovery of non-fraudulent underpayments. The question of fraud has not, at this stage, been determined but is subject to examination. Investigation into whether fraud occurred or not is not yet completed. In respect of that matter, vehicles from both Japan and Europe are involved. Those investigations aim to determine full details of transactions between the suppliers and the importers in Australia, and the exact role played by a number of other parties-there are a number of parties involved-and the nature of the services provided to ship vehicles to Australia. The Australian Government Solicitor has been involved and his advice sought on a number of occasions. That advice recognises that in a number of places further information is necessary before final conclusions can be reached. That question of obtaining further information is now well down the track.

ANSWER.PARA: I should say that because of the relative insignificance of duty per vehicle involved, the Customs Service did not regard seizure as an important consideration at that time. I should also say that arising from this particular incidence, the Customs Office, at my request-indeed, I think, of its own volition as well-has been trying to look at the wider ramifications of this issue. I hope to get a report on that at a later stage. Might I say that this is not the first incidence of goods being undervalued for duty. The Customs Service has been engaged in litigation with other companies in other industries in respect of the same sort of thing. I think it is a particularly difficult problem in areas where bulk goods are imported. For example, in the textile, clothing and footwear industries, the strategic and managerial problems of investigating all those matters are very great. It is something that I hope we will get some solution to from the Customs Service in the near future.

The Interim Director has confirmed that he became confused about the breakdown of the costs when answering the question. There was no cost escalation and I am sure that Senator Puplick will also be interested in that because he evinced a great enthusiasm in pursuing this matter also. The $8,000 was an initial estimate in relation to the printing of a brochure only. The $50,000 is made up of $28,000 for a video, which is well within the normal market price, and $22,000 for the brochure. Of this, $14,000 was for the corporate design, which is similar to design costs for other institutions.

The museum has been developing promotion material of this nature in order to publicise its existence and it is clear that this material will be of much use to the museum in attracting interest and support as it will be a lasting and valuable record of Australia's marine heritage. I suppose that that is clear to those who have seen the video; I have given the information from the Department. Like the honourable senator's office, I have not seen the video so I suppose that it is not clear to us yet. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I did not in fact ask about the video; I asked simply about the brochure. I thank the Minister for her reply. She did say in her reply relating to the activities of the Department of Finance that she did not know whether or not the allegations were true. I ask her: Are they true?

—I do not have any information that would allow me to answer that question precisely. But I did say that, in my view, the comments of the officer were inappropriate because they went to areas that were not his responsibility. However, the further information that has been supplied to me by that Department today assures me, and I now assure the Senate, that it is not correct to say that the Department of Finance is responsible for the escalation in the costs of this material.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that the Queensland Government intends to borrow $20m in Europe to tidy up several country race-tracks in a pre-election spending spree? Can the Minister inform the Senate to what extent Australia's overseas debt is attributable to State governments and State authorities borrowing overseas? Will the Government do anything to prevent State governments jeopardising Australia's economic stability with such self-interested political grandstanding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate asked me whether I was aware that the Queensland Government intends to do all these dreadful things. I am aware of a report in the Australian newspaper, which is not dated, on which Senator Tate's question apparently is based. So, I am aware of the report. Senator Tate asked whether the Government will do anything to prevent State governments behaving in that way. Under the present financial system it is difficult to prevent them from behaving in that way. But I think it ought to be noted that, in all the debate about whether borrowing overseas constitutes, on balance, a net economic problem for Australia, it is useful to distinguish between at least three qualitatively different types of borrowing. Whether it aggravates our long term debt provision in borrowing for takeovers depends on what those people who sell the shares do with the money they receive. If it is used to invest, in the economic sense, in productive activity which will either replace imports or generate exports, it could be a net benefit to Australia to borrow overseas.

ANSWER.PARA: There can be no doubt that, if overseas borrowings are resorted to, to squander on self-indulgences and topping up pork barrels of the type that the Queensland Government proposes, it will aggravate our external account and our longer term economic position. It is also interesting insofar as it reveals where the Queensland Government's priorities lie. Queensland has the worst schools in the country, the worst economy in the country, the highest rate of venereal disease, ex-nuptial births and teenage pregnancies, all of which, of course, are a function of the sexual ignorance which prevails in Queensland and which that Government is dedicated to perpetuating. On the specifics of the amount to which State governments have contributed to foreign debt, according to Loan Council data the level of overseas debt of State non-monetary authorities was just over $9 1/2 billion which was about 44 per cent of total public sector overseas debt. The Loan Council figures do not have the same basis as Australian Bureau of Statistics figures. In spite of that, the level of State authorities' overseas debt is in the order of 14 per cent of total gross overseas debt, both public and private, and State borrowings, of course, are subject to Loan Council restraints. Perhaps in that way the Commonwealth Government may be able to exercise some pressure on Queensland to cease doing this sort of thing.

In conclusion, I do not know whether or not the $5m which is to be borrowed by the Queensland Government to spend on the Mackenzie River Dam-which is otherwise known as the John Bjelke-Petersen benefit lake-will be borrowed overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, follows the earlier questions relating to a possible conflict of interest in a ministerial committee. I refer the Minister to his declaration of pecuniary interests lodged with the Prime Minister on 12 September 1983 which disclosed that he was a director of the Industrial Printing and Publicity Co. Ltd, the beneficial shareholders of which are branches of the Australian Labor Party and various trade unions. I ask the Minister whether he is still a director of that company. I further ask whether he can confirm to the Senate that Industrial Printing and Publicity is the registered holder of 58,661 shares in the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, the value of which has increased in the past 24 hours by about $44,000 to $430,000, and that at the time of the ministerial committee meetings it stood to make a profit of more than $80,000 if the shares had been sold at the price then on offer. Did the Minister consider that such a substantial shareholding by a company of which he is or was a director, in the words he read out in the Senate in September 1983, may give rise to a conflict of interests?

—I am a director of the Industrial Printing and Publicity Co. Ltd as my return of pecuniary interests shows. I am a director of that company as a trustee for certain organisations, some of which Senator Chaney mentioned in his question. I am not in receipt, I have never been in receipt, nor am I eligible for the receipt of any dividends from that company. I am not in receipt of any remuneration as a director. I was, but when I became a Minister in this Government I cancelled any remuneration arrangements that I might have had with that company. I am not aware of the shareholding of BHP. I have not attended as a member of the Board of that company, I think, since I became a Minister. I am not aware of the extent of any BHP shareholding. I probably would have been aware that the company held shares in a wide number of industrial stocks but I could not say which companies.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I acknowledged in my question the apparent trustee status of the Minister but does he agree that, as a director of that company, he owed a duty to that company and to its shareholders and that there was a possibility that that duty to the company and to its shareholders could conflict with his ministerial duties?

—I acknowledge that, under the Companies Act, I have a duty to the shareholders of that company. I do not believe that any conflict with my ministerial duties is occasioned by that fact. As a matter of fact, if Senator Chaney likes to study the Senate record, for example, I have in the Senate declared my interest as a director of that company in relation to a debate on a broadcasting matter. At that time I was an active director of the company and in receipt of remuneration as a director; in the Senate I publicly declared my interest. But I do not believe that in respect of my current role with that company I am involved in any conflict of interest.

—My question is to the Minister for Community Services. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the statements made yesterday in the other place by Mr Ian Cameron, the honourable member for Maranoa, and widely reported in today's papers that, firstly, women should be encouraged to stay at home and look after their families and not bring them up in some `socialised, ratbag, Russianised-type child-minding centre set up at the factory door'; secondly, that he supports the recent statement by the Queensland Minister for Welfare that the supporting parent benefit should be abolished; and, thirdly, that he would extend this by not paying an allowance even for the first child? Does the Minister care to comment on these outrageous claims, in particular the aspersion cast upon children's services in this country and the effect of removing the supporting parents benefits from single parents? Also, will the Minister, in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Health, comment on whether Mr Cameron's claim that he has worked his guts out suggests that he is gutless?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one of the doctors in this place, I take a leaf out of the book of my legal colleagues in this place and will not give medical opinions in this place, so I will have to ignore the last part of Senator Crowley's question. I certainly did see the references this morning in the newspapers and partly in Hansard to Mr Cameron's speech. It seems to me that Mr Cameron wants two things to happen. First of all, he wants women to stay at home. I understand that he insists that his wife stay at home. He also wants no support to be provided in the many instances where one person, be it male or female, has to look after children, through circumstances beyond their control.
—Does he want to abolish the widow's pension?

—I assume, as Senator Walsh says, that he probably wants to abolish the widow's pension too. I find it extraordinary that he should describe child care centres as socialised, ratbag, Russianised and all sorts of extraordinary things, because even in the electorate of Maranoa, Mr Cameron's electorate, he has child care centres and family day care centres.
—Close them down.

—I will close them down, if that is what he wants. But I would not like to do that because Mr Cameron, as the local member, has approached me and my Department for assistance for funds to set up such centres.
—Double standards.

—Of course, we are used to double standards from those sorts of people. He and the new Minister for Community Welfare in Queensland have in recent times had a fair bit to say about child care centres and about the supporting parent benefit. Both of them have said at various times that the supporting parent benefit should not be paid and that they are sick of working to support single parents. They have both also criticised child care centres in the way that Mr Cameron did yesterday. How he or Ms Chapman from Queensland can suggest that we should abolish the supporting parent benefit, leaving people totally unsupported, and at the same time suggest that what these people should do is stay at home and look after their kids, is beyond me. I do not understand that logic. But then again I do not suppose that logic is a strong point in either case.

ANSWER.PARA: I resent their description of children's services in this country as Russianised, socialised, communist or however else they describe them. One of the penalties that face Ministers in charge of child care in this country-people like Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, Senator Chaney and me-is that we end up with very harrowed looks a lot of the time because, as Ministers in charge of that area, on one side we are attacked by the people who want child care for not providing enough of it, and on the other side we are attacked by people like Mr Cameron who want us to provide none at all. In fact children's services are an essential part of this society and any modern society. They are provided not only for people who need to work; they are provided not only for single parents; they are also provided as respite care-`take a break care', if you like-for those many women in this country who live in isolated circumstances in our suburbs, our mining towns, our large cities and our country towns.

Continual representations come to me, to Ministers such as Senator Ryan and to all members and senators in this Parliament from women who wish to be provided with more child care than is available. They are not assisted by the outbursts from people like Mr Cameron. They are not assisted by the vicious statements and prejudicial views expressed by Mr Cameron. The only thing I can hope is that his views are largely his own or at least just the views of the National Party of Australia that he represents. They are certainly reflected in this place by Senator Boswell, Senator Bjelke-Petersen and particularly Senator Sheil. I hope they are not the views of members of the other coalition party. If they are, I feel sorry for the people whom they represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It refers to his previous answer to a question from me. —I refer to Ministers; not one Minister of the previous Government, in the seven years of that Government, declared a conflict of interest in this place. —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I note the Minister's total failure to answer the three points I raised with him. Ltd with $400,000 worth of shares?

—I certainly did not make any declaration in the Senate in relation to this matter because I was never asked to do so. The Leader of the Opposition needed a couple of smutty journalists to draw his attention to my public declaration of interest. He needed a couple of journalists to help him out with that. No Opposition senator ever asked me about that. They had plenty of opportunity but nobody ever asked--
—In the Cabinet room.

—I declined, in answer to an earlier question from Senator Chaney, to answer on what happens in the Cabinet room. I simply said that I would not reveal the nature of Cabinet room discussions on that question.
—Covering up.
—Covering up, if you want.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What action is the Government taking to encourage the United States to agree to sign the protocols for the South Pacific nuclear free zone? Will the Minister be seeking dialogue with the governments of other countries with the aim of establishing further nuclear free zones in our region? Does the Minister believe that this Government's preparedness to mediate and negotiate to reduce tensions and establish zones of peace in our region is a valid and proper role for Australia to play in this International Year of Peace?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The idea of a South Pacific nuclear free zone treaty became a South Pacific Forum undertaking in 1984 when heads of government established a working group of officials chaired by Australia to draft a treaty. Since that time Australia has worked as a member of the Forum team to bring the treaty and its protocols-which was the particular subject of Senator Elstob's question-into being. In January-February this year, the chairman of the working group, Mr David Sadleir of the Department of Foreign Affairs, led a delegation representative of the Forum to explain the treaty and its draft protocols to the five nuclear weapons States and to solicit their views on the protocols. The full working group is meeting this week in Fiji to consider the delegation's report and to frame recommendations to Forum heads of government on finalisation of the protocols. Beyond all this, in the course of regular bilateral exchanges with the United States at all levels, we have had occasion to explain the intent and effect of the treaty and to respond to questions and requests for clarification. Beyond saying that, it would be inappropriate at this stage to comment further on the nature of the United States Government's response.

ANSWER.PARA: Other than the South Pacific nuclear free zone, Australia is an active participant in the United Nations ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean dealing with the proposal to establish an Indian Ocean zone of peace. As to the last part of Senator Elstob's question, the Government believes that a preparedness to work to reduce tensions is very much a valid and proper role for Australia in all years, including, of course, the International Year of Peace.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the Minister aware that already this year more than 20 people have died in Italy from contamination of wine by methyl alcohol? Is the Minister further aware that the rate of import of wine grape juice into Australia has doubled since 1982-83 and that over one-third of this wine grape juice is imported from Italy? What tests are regularly carried out on imported foodstuffs to ensure their safety for human consumption? In particular, what steps are being taken to ensure that Australians are not being put at risk from the importation of wines and wine grape juice from Italy? In view of the above and of the problems of the wine grape growers in Australia, what steps have been taken to control the import of grape juice into Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator Vigor's interest in alcoholic beverages. I think that on a previous occasion he asked me a question about Australian wine which was being sold in Japan and mistaken for Austrian wine which was said to have been contaminated. The Australian Government has been assured by the Italian Government-this matter has been adverted to-that no contaminated wine has been exported to Australia, and we have accepted these assurances. I should say that tests are regularly carried out on imported foodstuffs to ensure their safety for human consumption. I am not sure whether it is correct to infer from that answer that regular tests are carried out in relation to alcoholic beverages. The Australian Customs Service has been monitoring imports of wine from Italy to ensure that none of the affected brands are coming into this country. Apparently the brands which are alleged to have been contaminated have been quite clearly identified.

ANSWER.PARA: Imports of wine grape juice and so on into Australia have been fairly significant in recent years. However, the rate of increase has dropped since the beginning of this year. This is largely attributed to the changes in the exchange rate. Total imports of these wines into Australia represent only 4 per cent of the domestic market. The Department of Primary Industry has been monitoring imports of grape and wine grape juice since the sales tax on wine was imposed in 1984 and the independent inquiry into the wine and grape industry has recommended that there is a need to continue that monitoring. It will continue.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PRATT AND WHITNEY JT8D JET ENGINES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. Did the Minister see the recent article in the Adelaide Advertiser entitled `Jet Engine Still Risky'? The article says that in the United States doubts have surfaced over the adequacy of Federal Aviation Administration directives in respect of the Pratt and Whitney JT8D jet engines. This engine was considered to be the cause of aircraft accidents in Milwaukee and Manchester last year and is particularly important as it powers many of the world's commercial airliners. Can the Minister state whether Australian aviation checks on these engines are adequate in this context and whether aviation directives currently in force are adequate to cope with this situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware, as is the Minister for Aviation, of the article which appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser a couple of days ago headed `Jet Engine Still Risky'. It concerns the Government that there is such a strong division of opinion on the issue in the administration of aircraft safety in the United States. The article highlighted differences of opinion over safety which apparently have arisen between the two arms of the United States Administration responsible for domestic aviation, one known as the National Transport Safety Board and the other as the Federal Aviation Administration. At least in this country we are fortunate that we do not have such divided responsibilities.

ANSWER.PARA: Aircraft fitted with this engine were involved in the Manchester, United Kingdom, Boeing 737 accident and then the Milwaukee DC9 accident in the United States. The National Transport Safety Board has expressed its concern that engines with high numbers of takeoffs and others that have an older, weaker design of engine spacer are not inspected more urgently. The present Federal Aviation Administration timetable, according to the other organisation, would not detect early stages of cracking that could lead to engine failure. The divided opinion in the United States naturally causes concern, not only in that country but in all countries using those aircraft. The Australian Department of Aviation shares the concern expressed by the National Transport Safety Board and already has taken action in Australia in line with its recommendations. We will keep the honourable senators informed of the progress on those recommendations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind the Leader of the Government, who is a lawyer, of his responsibilities as a director. I quote from the Australian Corporate Affairs Reporter which quotes Lord Cranworth as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: The director owes a fiduciary duty to his company. It is incumbent on him to assume no part which would be inconsistent with the proper, free and independent discharge of his duty. He cannot serve two masters. His personal interests and his duty as a director cannot be brought into conflict.

I draw the attention of the Minister to his own declaration of interests which concedes that the Minister's connection with the company to which I referred is a matter which could give rise to a conflict of interest with his ministerial duties. That is expressly stated in the Minister's own declaration. I ask the Minister: Did he make any declaration of his interests? If he will not answer that, I ask him: What has he to hide?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Chaney, at the start of his question, identified the quality of his question by saying that I am a lawyer and that I ought to understand the legal point of what--
—It is a pretty straightforward point for an honest man.
—Order! Senator Chaney!
—I am glad that Senator Chaney characterised his own question by pointing to the very legality of the point that under the Companies Act--
—I said that an honest man would understand it.
—Order! Senator Chaney, you have asked a number of questions. The Minister is entitled to be heard in silence.

—If Senator Chaney wants to have this on, I will name some people on the other side. Let him think about it for the next 24 hours and decide whether he wants to have it on, because I will have it on with him. The question relates to whether I am saddled in the deliberations of this Government and in this Parliament with a very nebulous duty imposed on directors of companies under the Companies Act and whether that gives rise to a conflict of interest. The rules about conflict of interest, as I understand them and as this Government understands them, are whether an individual will be personally influenced in his judgment as a result of the fact that he has something to gain or lose by the way in which his judgment is exercised.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney can turn that around as much as he likes but that is what I interpret `conflict of interest' to mean-whether an individual's judgment will be affected by whether he has something to gain or lose by the way in which he exercises that judgment. I declared my interest publicly as a director of the Industrial Printing and Publicity Co. Ltd. I have said in the Senate and I will say it again that I have nothing to gain or lose by anything that that company does. In contradistinction to members of previous governments--

TALK.START.PARA: —What if it goes broke?

—I have nothing to gain or lose. In contradistinction to members of previous governments, I immediately cancelled any benefit that I might have gained from that company when I became a Minister in this Government. In the past, when I was a director in receipt of remuneration from this company and a member of the Opposition-not a member of the Government-I declared my interest as a director of that company. No one on the Opposition front bench has done that.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: How long is it since the question of the establishment of a register of pecuniary interests of senators was referred to the Senate Standing Orders Committee? What progress has been made by that Committee? Have Opposition members of the Standing Orders Committee, which include the Leader of the Opposition, shown any support or enthusiasm for the proposal? Will the Leader of the Government in the Senate discuss this matter with the Leader of the Opposition and attempt to obtain his support for a change in the Standing Orders? At the next meeting of the Standing Orders Committee will he ensure that the matter is brought to a conclusion so that the Standing Orders are changed and a register is established in accordance with Government policy, similar to that agreed to in the House of Representatives, so that conflicts of interest of anybody in the Government and, particularly, in the Opposition can be brought into the open?
—I can say with absolute certainty that the Opposition representatives on the Committee have shown no enthusiasm about the matter.
—Have you?

—Oh, yes. I must say that the Standing Orders Committee, of which I am a member, has not met as often as it might and perhaps has been less than diligent in pursuing this issue. One of the reasons for this is that it has been trying to devise a way around the total lack of enthusiasm or, if I might say so, the totally negative response from Opposition senators to any effort to introduce such a register.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PORT ARTHUR CONSERVATION AND DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Newman, I remind honourable senators that this will be the first time that she has asked a question in this place. I request that the normal courtesies be extended to her.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. As a preface to the question, the Minister will be aware that, in response to my questioning last night of the Heritage Commission in Estimates Committee D as to the pre-eminent importance of Port Arthur as an historic site and restoration project, it was agreed that the Government had made no provision for funds for the project to continue, that there had been no correspondence on the matter and that the specialist team of experts is already dispersing, due to the uncertainty of the project. In view of the urgency of the matter, could the Minister tell the Senate why her Government has allowed this nationally important project to be placed in jeopardy?

—I am certainly in no position to agree with the implication in the last part of the honourable senator's question. Certainly, I recall the discussion at the Estimates Committee hearing last evening about the Port Arthur project but I do not recall that any information given then would suggest that the project is in jeopardy, but rather that certain plans could not be implemented until funds were forthcoming. I have no information at hand to add to what was given to Senator Newman at the Estimates Committee hearing last night. I will pass her concern about this project, which relates to her State of Tasmania, to the Minister and see whether he has more positive information which he can make available to her.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has agreed with the basis on which I described the questioning at the Estimates Committee hearing last night. In view of that, I wonder how the Minister can explain the fact that, although her public servants said last night that there had been no correspondence on the issue, on 25 September last year a very detailed document for a four-year program was sent with the concurrence of the State-Commonwealth steering committee to the Federal Minister. I have telexes dated 16 January 1986 and 14 February 1986 which clearly show that the Federal Government is dragging its feet in this matter. I seek leave to have the documents incorporated in Hansard.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Private Secretary to
The Hon. J. Beswick,
Minister for National Parks
Tasmania
Receipt is acknowledged of Mr Beswick's telex of today's date concerning the Port Arthur conservation and development project.
I shall draw your minister's telex to the attention of Mr Cohen at the earliest opportunity.
Peter Conway
Senior Private Secretary
Office of the Minister for Arts,
Heritage and Environment
Canberra
The Hon. Barry Cohen
Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment,
Canberra.

I refer to my telex of 16 January 1986 concerning the Tasmanian Government's proposal that the Port Arthur conservation and development project be extended as a joint Commonwealth/State funded project for another four years.
Your senior private secretary acknowledged my telex indicating that it would be drawn to your attention at the earliest opportunity.

Although I have become increasingly concerned with continual Commonwealth delay in consideration of our proposal I took some heart from Senator Coates comments at the official opening of the restored commandants house at Port Arthur historic site on 25 January 1986. Senator Coates said that he had discussed the extension of the project with the Prime Minister and was confident that a decision would be made within ten days.
That period has now well and truly passed and enquiries at officer level this week have drawn the reaction that a decision was expected within two weeks.
It is now over four and a half months since our proposal was put to you and over three months since your personal inspection of the site on 8 November 1985.

The continual delays by the Commonwealth in considering this proposal are having a considerably destabilising effect on the conservation and development team staff and are also contributing to the loss of valuable knowledge and expertise as staff understandably protect the welfare of their families by seeking alternative and more secure employment elsewhere.

While Port Arthur historic site plays a significant part in the Tasmanian tourist industry it is also undoubtedly of national heritage significance and the Commonwealth Government has a clear responsibility to ensure that the ruins of the penal settlement that played such a pivotal role in the development of this nation are properly conserved and presented for future generations.
I would be pleased if you would now give this matter your immediate and urgent personal attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Black.
—I have not received an answer to the question.
—Order! There was no supplementary question. It was a supplementary statement.
—I take a point of order. My statement enclosed a question.
—Will the honourable senator repeat the question without the statement?
—How does the Minister explain the fact that that correspondence clearly shows that it is the Federal Government which is dragging its feet on the matter?

—I suggest that Senator Newman's supplementary was supplementary information. It certainly was not a supplementary question arising out of the way that she phrased her original question. Nonetheless, because she is a new senator and it was her first question, I will take the second aspect of her question on notice and seek a reply from the Minister.

—Is the Minister assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women aware of the equal opportunity law recently passed in the Japanese Parliament? Can the Minister comment on the similarities of this law and the affirmative action legislation which was passed by the House of Representatives this morning, especially in relation to penalty clauses.

—I was very pleased to read media reports of the Japanese sex discrimination Act. I was pleased because it is very common in this country for those who understand its industrial composition, as does my colleague Senator Button, to point to Japan as a model for the Australian economy. We hear a great deal about the Japanese car industry and steel industry. Indeed, Japan is a leader amongst the industrialised countries and has a very good economic record. It is very interesting and encouraging to see that in this case Japan is following the example of Australia. Like us, Japan has now introduced an Act outlawing discrimination in employment on the grounds of sex. Similar to the provisions in our affirmative action legislation, the Japanese legislation has avoided counter productive, punitive measures and has taken a constructive approach. The new law stops short of penalising bosses who violate it but provides that local equal opportunity mediation committees in each district will dispense advice and disputes about it. There have been some jovial interjections. I think it is important to establish that in these very important respects of equal opportunity in employment, Australia is a world leader because of the legislative program of our Government, and is offering leadership that even highly advanced, very successful economies such as Japan seem very eager to follow.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. When did the United States Government make its first approaches to the Australian Government regarding a possible fuel base in Western Australia and at what stage are the current negotiations? Given that it is cheaper to refuel in port than at sea on a quantitative basis, why are negotiations proceeding for a United States owned and controlled fuel base? If the land base supply of JP5 jet fuel is the issue, as the Minister indicated here yesterday, why cannot the Australian Government ensure that the current suppliers increase their stocks of that particular fuel to meet the United States Navy's requirements? Why is the Government considering an agreement which damages Australian sovereignty when it is clear that no agreement is necessary?
—Utter nonsense. It is because we do not have JP5 in Australia. We have avtur.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would Senator MacGibbon like to take over? This is a bipartisan defence policy, Mr President. Discussions with the United States on the provision of fuel supply in Western Australia have been underway since 1982. Several options have been explored. It is presently intended to reach an agreement to supply diesel fuel from HMAS Stirling in accordance with the 1984 Australian-United States memorandum of understanding on fuel exchange. Since the Royal Australian Navy does not hold, or have a requirement for, significant amounts of JP5 fuel in Western Australia, an agreement to permit commercial arrangements for the supply of JP5 is being discussed.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question about why negotiations are proceeding for a United States owned and controlled fuel base-as Senator Vallentine chooses to describe it-the Minister for Defence advises me as follows: Negotiations are not proceeding for a United States owned and controlled base. Current negotiations concern the possibility of the United States navy being supplied F76-whatever that may be-from RAN storage at HMAS Stirling and of the United States Navy entering a commercial arrangement to hire storage for JP5. It is quite incorrect to describe either of these arrangements in the terms used by the honourable senator. As to her third question, JP5 is the United States military specification for aviation turbine fuel used in ship borne aircraft. Australian commercial aviation turbine fuel has a different specification known as Jet A-1-that is subject, of course, to Senator MacGibbon's agreement--

TALK.START.PARA: —You're dead right.

—Good. Consequently, although Australian refiners have the ability to manufacture JP5 they would not normally have storage facilities available. The Australian Government does not have the authority to direct a particular refiner to increase or construct segregated storage particularly for a product for which the principal demand in Australia is for the American navy.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the final part of the question which goes to an issue of alleged potential damage to Australian sovereignty, the Government is not considering an agreement which, in any way, damages Australian sovereignty. As I have already said, we have proposed to the United States Government a basis of agreement which is designed both to satisfy United States needs and to protect Australian interests, including of course Australian sovereignty. In particular we have stipulated that the fuel is to be stored for routine operational needs, as I said the other day, and not as a strategic stockpile. We have also made it clear that agreement for fuel storage will not constitute prior approval for ships' visits to Western Australia. As I said yesterday, they will be considered on a case by case basis. Finally, any fuel storage arrangements which are reached with the United States Government will not change the nature of United States naval operations in our region. In particular, they will not in any way constitute home porting.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BRANDY, WHISKY AND RUM: MATURATION REQUIREMENTS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the Government decision to abolish the compulsory maturation requirements for brandy, whisky and rum contained in the Spirits Act 1906. Is the Minister aware that maturation is an essential, integral step in the production of brandy, whisky and rum without which the oxidation and chemical change does not occur to produce the taste, aroma and characteristics attributed to these spirits? In whose interests has this decision to abolish compulsory maturation been made? On whose advice was this action taken? What steps will be taken by the Government to prevent the market being flooded with cheap rotgut local or imported spirits?

—There speaks the authentic voice of a South Australian senator. Firstly, Senator Jessop alleges that maturation of brandy, whisky and rum is essential. If it is essential I am not quite sure why most other countries that produce it do not have the essential regulations that we have. I believe that there are very few countries where maturation under regulation is required as it has been required in Australia in the past. Secondly, the decision to abolish maturation is a decision to abolish it in a phase way and was made after lengthy consultations with the industry, various individual companies, the National Health and Medical Research Council and a wide range of bodies. I have been asked in whose interest this was done. It was done not in the interests of any particular person or organisation; it was done in what is believed to be--
—In good spirits.

—In good spirits as the honourable senator said, and in what is believed to be the best interests of the Australian industry having regard to changes in technology which have occurred overseas and which are occurring here. Those who advocate a retention of the existing rules seem to be against it, that is, they are against our adopting the latest technology in those industries. As Senator Jessop's question has obviously been very well written for him, I will obtain a very well written answer and make sure that all the detailed points that he raised are covered.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (PROPORTIONAL PORTABILITY OF PENSIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1986
TRADE PRACTICES (TRANSFER OF MARKET DOMINANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now move to the final amendment that I propose to move in Committee to the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill 1986. This amendment is in two parts. The first part, paragraph (c) is identical to the amendment moved by the Opposition-the so-called grandfather clause. The Australian Democrats did not support the Opposition's grandfather clause for a very good reason. It said simply that a Part A statement within the meaning of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act 1980 was lodged before the day on which the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill 1986 received royal assent, the existing section 50 should apply and the amended sub-section 50 (2C) should not apply. That was an attempt to ensure that the rules of the game were not changed in the middle of a very important takeover in this country. It had one serious flaw, simply that the takeover-the largest takeover in the country by Holmes a Court of our largest enterprise-was in progress, but the bidder, the Holmes a Court companies, could have circumvented the meaning of the Opposition's amendment simply by withdrawing the bid and reapplying it as soon as royal assent had been given to this Bill. Because it was so easily circumvented, the Democrats were unable to support the Opposition on their so-called grandfather clause, although, as I have repeatedly stated, we appreciated the intent of that clause. Both the Opposition and the Democrats agree that one should not change the rules in the middle of the most important takeover this country has seen.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the amendment now before us is simply to add paragraph (d) to the wording of the amendment presented by the Opposition. It says that if a Part A statement in respect of the acquisition of shares is lodged within six months after the day this Bill receives royal assent, the existing law, the old section 50, should apply and not the proposed new sub-section 50 (2C). If the Opposition were genuine in its desire to ensure that the rules of the game were not changed during the most important takeover this country has seen, it should have no logical or philosophical reason for opposing this amendment. It is very clear, it has been debated at length, and I do not wish to waste the time of the Committee labouring the point any further, but I would make a final point. We have seen in the last two days the spectacle of two public companies investing $3.5 billion worth of shares in a buying spree on the stock markets the like of which this country has never seen before. We are seeing this enormous amount of money-$3.5 billion-being invested for no productive purpose whatever, at a time when youth unemployment is the highest it has ever been, in excess of 20 per cent of our young people being unemployed. What could $3.5 billion do if it were invested in productive resources and in expanding the productive resources of industry?

Why are we seeing this enormous waste of funds, this enormous investment and speculation on the Stock Exchange, rather than in productive investment? We are seeing it because the Government is sitting back and saying: `This is no responsibility of ours. Where investors want to invest their money, let them go to it-that is no concern of ours. Whether the money comes from overseas or whether it does not is no concern of ours. When we have a foreign debt, the magnitude of which we cannot even meet the interest payments on, or we are very closely getting to that point, that is still apparently no concern of ours. We will let the market rip'. I suggest that this is not good enough, and that the very least we as parliamentarians can ask is that we should not make it easier for speculators than it already is. We should be concerned when the largest monopoly this country has ever had is about to be taken over under circumstances that the public are completely in the dark about. Therefore, I move:
Page 2, clause 3, proposed new sub-section 50(2c), at the end of proposed sub-section, add:
`, unless, in the case of an acquisition of shares-

(c) a Part A statement within the meaning of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act 1980 or of a corresponding law of a State or Territory in respect of that acquisition of shares by that person was lodged with the National Companies and Securities Commission in accordance with that Act or such a law before the day on which the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Act 1986 received the Royal Assent; or

(d) such a Part A statement in respect of an acquisition of shares by that person in a body corporate is so lodged within 6 months after that day, and a Part A statement in respect of an acquisition of shares by that person in that body corporate was so lodged in the circumstances referred to in paragraph (c).'.
In moving this amendment, we concede that this is a last ditch attempt to hope that logic prevails in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Such was the degree of confusion prevailing when we debated this matter for about eight minutes before the last adjournment that when Senator Siddons substituted an amendment for that which he had previously laid down and I opposed it, the particular proposal I was opposing was in fact the one we are now debating, not the one he then substituted. Such, however, was the degree of interest shown by Senator Siddons in what I was saying and by anyone else in this chamber that nobody noticed. That simply leads me to say that it is not necessary now to respond to Senator Siddons's latest amendment, because I already did so the last time round. I hasten to add, lest anybody be further confused, that the bottom line was no different so far as the last amendment was concerned than it is for this one. We oppose them both, albeit for slightly different reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: May I quickly summarise the problems with this current amendment now before the Committee. The first problem is that it does not do any better than any of its predecessors in ensuring that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-Bell takeover-if anyone is still interested in it, given other events that are occurring in that market at the moment-will in fact be the subject of scrutiny under section 50. It would be possible to circumvent Senator Siddons's amendment, for example, as currently drafted, simply by changing the legal entity seeking to make the acquisition-that is to say, the subsequent Part A statement could be lodged by a different legal entity, for example, an associated company. One could drive the appropriate tram through the amendment now before us.

The second point to make is that it is possible to defeat the amendment in another way by simply delaying the subsequent Part A exercise for six months and one day before another bid is issued. The time limit here of six months is just as arbitrary as the 12 months time limit that was subject to criticism by both sides of this chamber in respect of Senator Siddons's first amendment in this series.

The final point I make is one I made just before lunch, and that is that the amendment as drafted would not apply to asset acquisitions or on-market takeovers of the kind set in train by lodgment of a Part C statement. Accordingly, the amendment is discriminatory in the way it operates. It has no foundation in principle that one can discern. It is obviously simply an attempt-not a very successful attempt, with the utmost respect to Senator Siddons's advisers-to find some way of stymieing a takeover which they do not want to go ahead, for reasons unconnected with the continuing merits, which are non-existent, of section 50 of the Trade Practices Act as applied to bare transfers of monopoly power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would point out that we are not trying to stymie a takeover. What we are trying to do is allow the existing law to operate on a takeover bid that has been made under the terms of the existing law. It is very misleading for Senator Evans to say that we are trying to stymie a takeover. We are saying that, if it were reasonable for a monopoly to occur under the existing law, that law should remain and the due processes implicit in the existing law should take place. We are not trying to stymie anything. Our position has always been, and still is, that we are not taking sides. We are just saying that in a takeover of this magnitude there should be an inquiry. The existing law would allow it to happen. This amendment will stymie an inquiry, or at least stymie the Trade Practices Commission from ruling on whether it thinks there is grounds for legal action or not in the Holmes a Court bid. That is all we are trying to do.
—How do you feel about John Elliott-just as passionately?

—I have already said, Senator, that it is a disgusting state of affairs that we have witnessed in the last two days with $3.5 billion being invested in speculation-that is what it boils down to. That money will not add one iota of productive capacity to this country at a time when over 20 per cent of our young people are unemployed. That is my position. I put out a Press statement today on that. It is quite obvious that these enormous amounts of money underline the importance to the investing public, to industry generally and, I would have thought, to the Government of at least allowing the existing law to operate and not change it in the middle of the business. An amount of $3.5 billion has been invested in the last two days and yet the Government stands in this chamber and says: `Let us change the laws so we can make it easier for one of the parties which have spent this enormous amount of money to achieve its objective'.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been accused of being unduly persevering in this matter. I have been accused of a whole lot of things by Senator Gareth Evans. He stood up and said that he could drive a bus through the legalities of my amendments. That may or may not be true. I do not believe this chamber is the place to debate highly complex legalities. If the principles that I have been espousing mean anything to the Government and the Opposition, they should at least allow this piece of legislation to go to a committee for a short time so that some of the things which have been said in this debate at least can be evaluated. We are not trying to suggest anything other than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you support the Opposition's referral of the whole Bill to a committee when we moved for it before?

—For a very good reason. I acknowledge Senator Durack's interjection. I think it has now become abundantly clear to all parties that the Opposition was happy to refer the whole of this trade practices legislation to a committee for no other reason than it wanted to delay amendments of the trade practices legislation per se. It was prepared to support the sending of the whole of the legislation to a committee but when the legislation was split it was not prepared to support this part of the legislation going to a committee. We can only assume that the reason for the Opposition's agreement to refer the whole of the legislation to a committee was its concern for the other part of the legislation and not for this part. I think that has become abundantly clear.
—We can assume that you are concerned only about this part and not the other part.

—One could say that. I accept that. In that sense the Government has at least flushed out the situation. We always were of the opinion that it was urgent to get trade practices legislation amendments through the Parliament. In spite of that attitude we said: `Look, we will block the whole of the legislation rather than let the section 50 (2C) amendment go ahead without any debate'. I will be interested to hear what the Opposition says about our amendment. I do not accept Senator Gareth Evans's comment that he could drive a bus through the amendment. One just cannot pull companies off the shelf and say: `Right, we will now lodge a bid in some other company's name'. It is not as easy as that, particularly when talking about amounts like $2 billion. I believe paragraphs (c) and (d) of the amendment would have the effect of allowing the existing law to apply to a current takeover bid. That is the purpose of them and I believe the amendment would allow that to happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be supporting this fairly patent attempt to try to indicate that the amendment is somehow in line with the Opposition's grandfather clause by putting in the first limb, which is in the same terms as the Opposition's amendment, and then adding another limb which raises an entirely different subject whatsoever. I have tried to explain over and over again that what the Opposition had in mind in moving an amendment in the same terms as paragraph (c) of the amendment was that when a specific takeover proposal is lodged in a proper legal manner the law as it is at that time should apply to that particular proposal. When people make takeover offers they have a knowledge of what the law is. They make the takeover offer in the knowledge of the state of that law. That is the law that should apply to those takeovers which are on foot in a legal way.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Siddons talks about a takeover offer as though it is some sort of stream of consciousness in his mind or Mr Holmes a Court's mind and one does not know where it all begins or ends. If one thinks about it in those terms, what is the significance of the period of six months or 12 months? We know that Holmes a Court has been talking about a takeover of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd for several years. Under that frame of thinking, that could go on for some more years. It becomes an absurdity.

The only point the Opposition has ever made here is that when a person makes a takeover bid in a formal legal sense, when he takes that step, that takeover bid should be judged and determined in the light of the law as it is at the time. If there is, as there is, a facility for that offer to be withdrawn and another one lodged after the law has changed, so be it if that suits the person or company concerned. It may or may not suit the person or company concerned. There may have been particular reasons why they wanted to proceed with that takeover bid knowing what the state of the law was then. There may be particular reasons why they would want to take advantage of the law if it changes, if they can and if the market stays much the same. This sort of market changes daily. These judgments are made by the people concerned in this takeover game and it is not for us to speculate on their judgments.

As Senator Gareth Evans has already said, this seems to be simply some desperate attempt by the Australian Democrats to ensure that the particular takeover proposals that are being made by Bell Resources Ltd are to be judged under the Trade Practices Act. As far as I know everybody agrees-even the Democrats-that the existing Trade Practices Act is not a suitable vehicle for judging the takeover of a monopoly or the bare transfer of monopoly power or whatever one likes to call it. The law needs to be changed. Whether it is replaced by some other law is a matter that we could continue to debate in this chamber, but everyone agrees that the existing law is quite unsatisfactory and that we should be proceeding to remove that law in those circumstances. People can decide, given the state of the law then, whether they want to proceed under the changes we make or to carry on under the law as it stood at the time they made the takeover bid.

That is all the Opposition has said in relation to this matter. As to the sort of additional limb that Senator Siddons has suggested, the only difference between it and his previous amendment is that this one is for six months and the previous one was for 12 months. There are some other things as well, but the essential difference is that one of time. Senator Siddons can keep on trying to bait the Opposition or tempt the Opposition by changing the days. He may come back next time with six days or something. He might come back and come down like an auction system. He has bid for 12 months. Now it is six months. Will he bid three months, or six days, or three days, or what?

The fact of the matter is that this whole exercise exposes a total misunderstanding by Senator Siddons of what the Opposition's amendments mean. We shall not move away from the principle that we have espoused throughout this debate. This amendment raises a completely different proposition and an absurdity. The Democrats are worried about Mr Holmes a Court's being able to proceed with a takeover offer for BHP, but he will be around. He has been around for several years already indicating this desire. What will another six months matter to him? It will not have any effect on what I assume to be the Democrats' purpose. Therefore, for those reasons the Opposition will not be supporting this additional amendment that the Democrats have proposed.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Siddons's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I want very briefly to speak to my amendment. During this debate Senator Gareth Evans said that he had no idea what was in the public detriment. I believe that that is an outrageous statement for a Government Minister to make. We agree that there could be some argument in determining the public detriment guidelines, and that only. For that reason I believe that the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill should go to a committee so that some consideration can be given to it and there is some clarification of what is a public detriment issue and what is not. We could easily list some of the public detriment matters, such as tax. What about negative gearing and the tax considerations there? What about our foreign debt, the increased debt for no gain in our productive resources? What about de facto foreign control of industry? Surely these things are in the public detriment or potentially could be? What about restructuring plans, assets stripping, closing plants and investment plans? Which areas will new investment go into?

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that, very clearly, all these things are in the public detriment or could be and it would be a very appropriate thing for the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs to report on. That Committee could take this brief and consider the matter, I would think, in the space of about a month and come back and report to the Government. I make no apologies for this last effort to get some sanity into the situation that we have had to witness over the last few days. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a great deal of sympathy with the purpose of this motion. I have always been a strong advocate of the benefits of public examination of legislation by Senate committees, and the fact that a particular Bill is agreed as being desirable does not mean that there would not be benefit in public committee examination of whether other consequential changes should not be made to the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In this particular case, though, there are other factors at work. The consequence of agreeing to this referral to a committee would be that the present provisions giving the Trade Practices Commissioner the right to inquire into a takeover of an existing monopoly would remain in force until the committee reported, which I think would inevitably be several months at least. The trouble is that the criterion which the Trade Practices Commissioner would use in examining the proposed transfer of control of the existing monopoly-in this case the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd steel monopoly-would be whether the proposed transfer of control was in the public interest, and this would be a requirement that would be almost impossible to satisfy. In practice, in the past, the Trade Practices Commissioner, despite the wording of the Act, has tended to look at whether there is net public detriment, and this would be perfectly appropriate in an examination of the change of control of a monopoly. Nevertheless, in such an important takeover as that of BHP, the Trade Practices Commissioner might well feel bound by the wording of the Act, and the majority of my Party, therefore, did not feel that a committee referral was desirable. Nor, for that matter, did BHP think a Trade Practices Commissioner inquiry, using existing criteria, was appropriate, though I suspect that BHP at the time was considering this only as an alternative to a full public inquiry. In the event, of course, it got neither.

I cannot understand the lack of interest by the Government in the very important matter of the transfer of ownership of a monopoly. Under the Trade Practices Act there is full examination of an acquisition leading to a new monopoly, and included in this would, of course, be the source of funding of the new owner as well as the proposed activities of the new monopoly. Yet when an existing monopoly is to be transferred to new ownership, the Government seems to have almost no interest.

Yesterday, Senator Gareth Evans argued that a secret inquiry by a Cabinet committee was an adequate substitute for a public inquiry. This is absurdly naive. There are many objections to such an inquiry, not least the lack of relevant competence of the Ministers concerned who are dealing with a highly complex area. In this case they were dealing with a man who has been publicly described by a Victorian Supreme Court judge as making, in another context, `highly misleading if not deceptive statements'. To trust such an important decision to naive Ministers is an absurdity. They are about as competent as the Victorian Football League commissioners who thought they were selling the Sydney Swans to Dr Edelsten, only to find that the real controller was someone quite different whom they had never heard of.

Worse still, the Cabinet committee hearing was in secret, so of course there are inevitably rumours about the `under the counter' deals that were done. This is inevitable if such inquiries are held in secret. We still have not heard any statements on the undertakings given at the secret hearing, nor what was said about the financial arrangements, despite the fact that the original reason for non-disclosure-the hearings before the Victorian Supreme Court-is now no longer relevant. But even when the disclosures are made-if they ever are-they will inevitably be incomplete and there will be lingering suspicion about what was not revealed. Such a Cabinet committee inquiry is the worst possible way to tackle such a complex issue. But because of the grossly inept handling of the whole matter by the Government, that is all we and the public will get.

When the tumult and the shouting over this particular takeover have died away, I believe we need a Senate committee to look into whether a public inquiry into the transfer of ownership of a monopoly is justified and, if so, who should conduct it and what criteria should be used. The committee might also usefully look at whether any control should be exercised over the activities of a monopoly to see that it is performing in the public interest. It is all very well for the Trade Practices Commissioner to decide that the establishment of a new monopoly is in the public interest, but what happens if it does not perform as promised? At the moment we can do nothing.

I think an investigation on the lines I have suggested would be a very important task for a Senate committee. One of the problems is that we would not have the power to compel the Government to take action if any action was recommended. This Government rather likes monopolies, particularly labour monopolies, and stoutly resists any attempt to ensure that the activities of the monopolies are in the interests of the public rather than themselves. This is the reason I was rather attracted to having such an inquiry conducted while we had government legislation before us, because then we have some power to make the Government take action that ought to be taken. Nevertheless, the majority of my Party felt the disadvantages of this course outweighed the advantages and I am prepared to abide by its decision, though I repeat it is very important that we have a Senate committee inquiry because there are real problems with monopolies; in particular those of the change of control of an existing monopoly, and how we ensure that established monopolies continue to operate in the public interest.
