DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Snowy Mountains Ski Tube Fire-Maritime Museum: Brochure

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 4.15 p.m., under Sessional Order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use this adjournment debate to draw the Senate's attention to an extremely serious occurrence which was reported in numerous newspapers on Thursday. I refer to the Snowy Mountains ski tube fire. It was caused by a spark from an oxy-acetylene torch igniting poly- urethane foam which was used to stabilise steel supports in the tunnel where there is a weak section of rock. This accident could quite easily have resulted in the loss of many lives. The response from the New South Wales Minister for Planning and Environment, Mr Carr, was that the most urgent question was why welding work was allowed near such a highly inflam- mable and toxic substance. I disagree only in emphasis with Mr Carr. I agree with the seriousness of the problem. The most important question was why governmental authorities allowed the use of polyurethane in the first place, especially in such a restricted and confined space, knowing the nature of the material used, the type of construction, the restricted nature of access and the type of equipment used in the construction of the tunnel. I believe that government authorities, including health, construction and building authorities, and the supervisors directly involved were mainly to blame. The inquiry will test that.

SPEECH.PARA: As a senator who has experienced a fire involving a welder in a room-in this case it was a similar substance, a polystyrene ceiling-I have ardently campaigned for its total abolition, or at least to ensure that adequate protective materials be incorporated in the construction because of the highly toxic nature of these sorts of materials when ignited, especially when, for example, on ignition the residue falling from the roof would stick to the skin, causing very extensive burning. A project of this magnitude-$40m in the first stage-should have been thoroughly vetted by government authorities prior to approval being given for commencement. To allow the use of such a volatile material as polyurethane must raise serious doubts about the efficiency and effectiveness of the local government and government authorities involved in supervision.

Fortunately, as I mentioned earlier, there was no serious injury but had this tunnel been operative many lives could have been lost due to the toxic fumes and burns. A further matter which must be raised was why this material, polyurethane foam, which is proven when ignited to produce toxic gases, including cyanide and nitrous oxide, was allowed to be installed in such a restricted place. Following, is the further question of whether the foam was to be placed in support of a concrete pour or was to be placed there permanently. Far more serious questions must be considered if it was to be there permanently. In fact, polyurethane resins can be produced in forms varying from hard, glossy solvent-resistant coatings to abrasion and solvent- resistant rubbers, fibres and flexible to rigid foams. Of all applications the foams have been found to be the most useful. The more flexible foams are also employed in upholstery material for furniture, as rug backing, insulation and crash pads. The more rigid foams are employed as the core in structural and insulating laminates and as insulation in refrigeration appliances and vehicles.

Polyurethane and polystyrene are used in a number of common household goods, such as foam padding in lounge suites, rugs and bean bags. Many people, when purchasing such items, do not realise the potential danger of this material should a major fire occur. Fire involving polyurethane raises once more the whole question of flammability and of allowing the use of gaseous materials in furnishings, including carpeting in hotels, convention halls, and all places where large numbers of people congregate. I believe that the Insurance Council of Australia Ltd in particular-because it is in a prime position to provide warnings or to load premiums in instances where materials which, upon ignition, give rise to gaseous materials which are of great risk to the public-has been derelict in its duty about not giving adequate warnings, as have building construction authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government appears to have used undue pressure to force a public servant to change embarrassing evidence he gave before a Senate committee. (5) What action is being taken to prevent their extinction.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The official list of Endangered Vertebrates of Australia and its Island Territories, prepared by the ad hoc Working Group on Endangered Fauna of the Standing Committee of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers, includes 28 species of endangered birds.

(3) Which species are most endangered is open to some question, even amongst experts, and would depend partly on future land use and management policies of relevant State Governments and in Australia's Territories.

The Paradise Parrot, Northern Scrub Robin and Western Rufous Bristlebird are all thought likely to be extinct. The Lord Howe Island Currawong has an estimated population of less than 50 birds and the Norfolk Island Parrot may number less than 20 individuals. These particular species are threatened by habitat destruction, as are small remnant populations of Coxen's Fig Parrot, Plumed Frogmouth, Helmeted Honeyeater and Black-eared Miner.
The rarity of most of these species makes their precise status and management requirements difficult to determine.

(4) The 28 bird species listed as endangered occur in widely scattered areas of Australia and in the External Territories though most now have quite restricted distribution ranges. Maps showing precise distributions for each species appear in the CONCOM list of Endangered Vertebrates of Australia and its Island Territories.

(5) Conservation and management of endangered bird species in Australia are primarily the responsibility of State and Territory Wildlife authorities. The Commonwealth Government has legislative responsibility for the protection of endangered species only in areas under its direct jurisdiction, such as Kakadu and Uluru National Parks and the external territories.

Recent action to protect endangered bird species in Australia's external territories include the declaration of two extensions to Christmas Island National park, proclamation of Norfolk Island National Park under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, the establishment of a monitoring programme for Abbott's Booby on Christmas Island and a captive breeding programme for Green Parrots on Norfolk Island.

Australia is a party to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service administers the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 through which Australia's obligations under the Convention are implemented. Under this Act, overseas trade in fauna is closely controlled, or prohibited where species are seriously endangered.

The Commonwealth Government also seeks to encourage and support research into endangered bird species through the Scientific Research and Surveys consultancy Program and through grants to State wildlife authorities under the States Assistance Scheme. Both programs are administered by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service.
